Q&A: Award Winning Movie Producer and Businessman Chad A. Verdi Discusses Hollywood Deals and Tech Investments in Apple and NXT-ID Inc.'s (OTCQB: NXTD) Wocket NEW YORK and POINT ROBERTS, Washington - May 19, 2014 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Verdi to Produce/Executive Produce Three Films with Oscar winning Director Martin Scorsese: Star studded actors include Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver "You may see a Wocket in a very famous Pocket" - C. Verdi Investorideas.com, a global news source covering leading topics and sectors including technology and entertainment, releases an exclusive Q&A with entrepreneurial movie producer, businessman and investor Chad A. Verdi of Rhode Island. Mr. Verdi discusses new and recent ventures including new movie deals and his investments in game-changing technologies, including Apple and biometric mobile security company NXT-ID Inc., (OTCQB: NXTD), which is currently preparing to launch its smart wallet, the Wocket™ (   www.wocketwallet.com), with advance orders starting May 28th. Mr. Verdi notes, "I am always looking ahead and I'm never satisfied with 'good enough', My goal is to partner with the best, hire the best talent and invest in leading edge companies.

Steve Jobs made Apple known for 'Think different', Richard Branson made his motto, 'Screw it , let's do it' and I live by 'Go big or go home'." Q&A Interview: Q: Investorideas.com This past year has already seen you reach some key milestones; making movies with the best in Hollywood, like Martin Scorsese and your investment in NXTD is up over 300 percent in less than a year. What are you most excited about for the balance of this year? A: Chad A. Verdi Well, that's a tough one. I guess I am the most excited about NXTD right now, only because they are about to launch the Wocket™ this month. Wocket™ is a smart wallet with a re-programmable single credit card device that operates under a secured system using biometrics. I feel it will change the way people make credit card payments worldwide. Everyone is trying to get in on this game with mobile payments, mobile wallets, mobile apps like LOOP and COIN. Everyone is trying to figure out the best way to do it. I think Wocket™ has the right approach; separate from your phone. Most people are concerned about what happens if they lose their phone or it gets stolen - what happens with all that payment info on your phone? With Wocket™, it's not a worry because after each transaction it basically goes back to a blank card. Your identity and payment info are safe! It's great to think I originally invested in this a few years ago and now it may become the leader in the payment sector that I thought it would! Q: Investorideas.com In terms of your investments, you invest in both large companies like Apple and Yahoo and other big tech and entertainment companies but you also take risks and invest in smaller companies with emerging technology like NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Where do you see the biggest potential pay-off? A: Chad A. Verdi I obviously wish I would have had the opportunity to get into Apple from the beginning. I would have bet big on it, just like I have with NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Companies that take a different path from what the competition is doing represent the biggest opportunity, if it works. Steve Jobs set the course for Apple, I still love the company but it's hard to know if the vision will stay intact. NXTD is still young and they are taking a revolutionary approach to payments and identity issues, very different from their competitors and I like that. In my opinion, I see a big risk/reward opportunity here today because they have a product that every consumer will want and currently needs. The Wocket™ can store over 10,000 credit cards/coupons, under a secured system. It's never been done before. If they are successful in delivering this product; the sky is the limit. They could be the next Apple and that is my second-largest holding. Q: Investorideas.com The company stated that they will launch the Wocket™ May 28th at the Plaza Hotel in New York and will be taking advance orders for the Wocket™ once the event is done. Will you be attending and will you be buying one once advance orders are opened up? A: Chad A. Verdi For sure I will be there supporting them and seeing first-hand how the Wocket™ is embraced. And of course, I will be buying many, many Wockets™! I will be giving them out to all of my actor and celebrity friends in Hollywood. Soon, you may see a Wocket™ in a very famous pocket! I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. Verdi Music and Talent Supervisor Media Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4090091About InvestorIdeas.com: InvestorIdeas.com is a global news source covering leading sectors including biotech stocks tech and mobile stocks, mining, energy, waters stocks, renewable energy stocks, beverage stocks and more. STATION: CNBC
NATIONAL

Maria: Welcome back. Shares of Cisco lowered to after saying Sthaels quarter may Fall Short of expectations, this despite a 12% Rise in the fourth quarter Earnings. Cent' Jim Goldman is in San Jose California with an Exclusive Sit down with Cisco CEO John Chambers. And you've got some breaking New. >> Yes, we have been able to confirm a story we talked to you about Monday, Yahoo!

Will take an Equity Snake Chinese leader Alibaba.Com, hearing Initially 35% As much as a billion dollars two have schedule add Press Conference tomorrow in China, we are hearing that Yahoo! Lin Deed have the capability of Acquiring as much as 49.9% Of Alibaba before the Company plans its IPO which currently right now is scheduled for February so we will keep an Eye on this developing story but it looks like Yahoo! Had be taking a significant Investment in the Chinese Internet Market and we saw how Hot that was with Baidu IPO just last Friday. Now to the story at hand, we are here in San Po Jose, Cisco Systems show indicationingity Network Technology by opening up up the NASDAQ Market Remotely for the very first time in NASDAQ History at a Facile Knee San Jose, Cisco Worlds Headquarters and joining us Live for a very first on CNBC is Cisco Crow John Chaembers. The Report yesterday, your Earnings for the fourth quarter very Good, seemed very Strong but there seemed to be some Weakness in the Forecast and your Stock Ising a 4% Hit this morning because of it. Where is the Weakness if that is is the Proper way to Character Ease that, what do you see in the Markets? >> Well, we had, we are very proud of our quarter, Record quarter in Net Income, Record quarters in he Earnings per share and very much in line in Theton 5% Guidance we have give innocent next three, five-plus years and when you look at the next several years in front of us you will see the same thing. Projecting orders Historically in the Mid to upper Teens and this quarter was the same and we anticipate Adding Q1 and Q2 of next year. What you are seeing is normal Seasonality from the very Strong Q4 to a slow are Q1 and will build throughout the Rear and comparison a book-to-bill from a year ago was below, by definite -- Definition Strou grow orders Faster than revenue and no change to Guidance will the by you will see a little bit slower than perhaps People anticipated no effect on 4r9 so it is surprising a little bit. >> Is there a concern, everybody seems to be thinking there is this recovery in I.T. Enterprise spending Globally. Is there a concern maybe it not recovering quickly and as strongly us hoped? >> Actually our Position continues to get stronger. We've Gained Market share in almost every Product Cat Grerk all six advanced Technology, grew in total over 30% Year Oh year, not only the number one player of in five of those six Technology we are Gaining Market share in almost all of them so our momentum is Good and our Guidance hasn't changed. 10 to 15%, Good balance across all the Market Segment from Storage providers to enterprise to Dmirbl Consumer, Good balance across can all our Products Angie on -- Geography. >> You heard me talk about Yahoo! And Alibaba and Baidu went Public last week, Serve talking about the opportunities that exist in Commune that it is the Greatest frontier in big I.T. And big Tech yet I listened to you on the call yesterday and you seemed you indicate there had was slow don't in Business, maybe Cisco's Business in China had been declining. Why can't the Company Crack what seems to be a Great opportunity for everyone else? >> Well, I think by the time it Becomes obvious to Moebs Team People is a Great opportunity it maybe a little bit late to get in the Market. We have 60 Market share in China, we've been very successful in the last ten years, the Majority of Networks. We think the local Competitors are very, very tough . Where the Market are grow, end I can't Recollect Eastern Europe, Rush Middle East, Africa and Latin America. India is an example that will probably be as Large as China in two years, a surprise we grew 40% Sequentially in over 75% Year Oh year. We Aligned our Geographies on these knew emerging Markets to where the Market going Tore three and years from now, not today but by the time you Ajust Forred to it is a little bit late. >> The Stock we saw earlier down 4% Today, Trading in such a Narrow Range. Seems some frustration on the Street this Stock just Cannot move, can't get out of out own way Ways one of the things an Analyst told me yesterday. What do you tell Shareholders waiting for this Company to break out? Do you Address the Dividend issue, the Company bought back $2.5 billion Worth of Stock this is Mart after significant Stock Repurchase plan the Company announce add few years back. People want maybe a Dividend, maybe something to Prop Prop these shares up what do you tell them? >> Thing we Produce the revenue growth in Theton 15% Range we believe is very Doable if we Execute right with the Proper Caveat the Stock will take Care of it Self. As a CEO you don't run your Company based on a daily or weekly or quarterly approach you think one, three and five years out. Almost all or Investments take three to five-years to work out and this week we are Investing in the second Wave of advanced Technology. We are Notting a no Figure --Ing a no Figure one -- Agnos test Ec one way or the other or San share buy Backs, spend.5 billion on buy back, Majority of Shareholders who want a Dividend actually do that so we will do what it Fakes. It we really Produce the growth and profits like the last two years and continue to do it the next three to five the Stock will take Care of it Self, Jim. >> Our Gang back in New Jersey wants to get the Involves, do call him John Basin Cysts I Kale him John and not Mr. Chambers. Maria you want to get in on this. >> Hi, how are you. >> Good morning, Maria. >> Thank you for being with us, we have the whole Team here Eager to quarter. But let me something you touched on that is it is not the CEOs job to Manage things over the near term and that really Hits in on and Targets in on something that is a Nymph the Untils are talking about and your CFO went out of your way to really Manage he can, and talk about the next quarter and telling Analysts, look, don't get too over optimistic. Is it Fair to say the Analysts are just way too optimistic and the estimates are way too high and you are just trying to Manage the expectations? >> I think Maria that would be the wrong Asimmssition so that you for giving me the chance to correct Twhachlt we're really talking about is you Ebb don't Manage your Company on a week by week week or monthly or quarterly basis. The Key Investment you make are one, three and five years which is what we are going to Dork entering New Markets like the Commercial Marketplace which grew 20% Its last year N. Terms of communicating with the Street we are very you you proud of having very Good effective Communication on telling People People what to expect. Our Guidance in the next three to Pfeiffer years Ha none not changed at all. Ton 5% Growth. Clearly understand the Stock's Value Assuming growth in the high Single Digit. Time will tell if we are right or the Street is right, I feel comfortable we will grow if that Range Range Barring a huge surprise. >> The Street has been speculating about Acquisitions and also went out of your way so say you don't know why Wall Street Analysts are giving Credence to speculation about a possible deal with Nokia. Can you Rule out a Large Acquisition at Cisco? >> We always want to be careful not comment on Rumors and direction but we are very predict Theable. We've acquired nine companies this year, we Acquire Small Company can, ideal Target 100 Engineers moving into New Technology such as with the Kiss Acquisition for Lynxs. The Acquisition very successful. You Acquire Large to Small, you partner Large to Large so when we think about Large companies halfway around the World, dramatically different Culture, Et Cetera it Extremely unlikely it would be any Truth those Type of Rumors but I wouldn't comment on those but if I would Bet Ton, I would Bet against it. David: John, --. >> Hawaii David, how you doing. David: I'm Fine. Lump together with this Debate about expensing Options that will become the Rule for many companies the end of this year. Do you believe Options are a cash expense? >> Well, I think we will Report anyway or Shareholders Wabts us to Report, of course we will comply with all Govern Regulations to go with it. So I do believe that Stocks personally, Stock Options are an Expeps, I do not. I believe they are Reflected in the Dilution of your shares. Having said that, I do understand the Majority of People do so Industry no problem reporting it in that Format, I just hope they ask us to Report in a and a half Reflects what the Options are really Worth because Overstating the expenses can be as Bad as under stating them in that Drik but we will provide all of the above. David: You do spend cash in order Sthaem Dilution from the option by Employees do not so that is Real cash I would Assume it is an expense? >> Well if you look at it I have no problem expensing it David for those that Wont want to do that and Goal in a Hodgecle Fashion. Buy back shares when Mows Exercise Orpgs that dramatically cuts Dill Louis so if you pass out 2% Of Options to flows and buy it back when you Costumers the Stock you about cut that 2% And would Good Gain back to 1/2 of 1% Dilution so we will guy all the above and Leapt the Market determine the Proper expense of Valuation over time. David: Thank you. Maria: John, thank you so much for being with us, John Chambers, CEO of Cisco Live in San Jose in California. And thanks to Jim Goldman. Up next, the Squawkback question of the day, where do you see the Federal Reserve stopping Interest rates? Go to the Westbound Site, CNBC on MSN. We will bring you the Answers right after this. [cc]

I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. urn:contentItem:58R8-JHV1-F0PR-7029-00000-00No Headline In Original2013-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexis

The "Exhibition of the Industry of All Nations" opened in May 1853 on Reservoir Square, New York and caused a tourist boom, similar to the one caused by the Great Exhibition in London two years earlier. Each day in one of the main halls a crowd gathered, huddling in front of a stage upon which stood a structure that appeared at first glance like a gallows. Above a platform rose a tall structure of wooden boards with ropes hanging off to both sides. As workmen took the strain, pulling the ropes taut, the platform rose bearing the inventor Elisha Otis as well as barrels and heavy boxes, until it reached 30 feet above the heads of the throng.

After a dramatic pause an assistant cut the hoists with an axe and the crowds gasped as they expected to see the engineer crash to the ground. But the platform only dropped a few inches and remained there, suspended in the air, held by Otis's patented safety device, the "safety hoister." Above the murmur of astonishment, Otis assured his stunned audience, "all safe, gentlemen, all safe." It was a spectacle that changed the history of the world. Otis had not invented the elevator, but had made it safe. Before Otis's innovation, few places in the world-apart from Sana'a, in Yemen-had buildings over five storeys high; within 50 years there were skyscrapers overlooking Manhattan.

Cities and technology have long influenced each other. Otis's elevator was invented at the same time as innovations in railways, sewers and steel manufacture; combined they would determine the shape and scale of the modern city. Today, we are experiencing a new technological leap: the intelligent city, which is being heralded with the same fevered, messianic optimism and hard sell as Stephenson's Rocket or Bazalgette's sewers. To be smart is to be modern, we are told; a failure to embrace the liberating power of information is to be morally suspect. But this poses the question of what precisely the role of technology might be in the modern city. Can it turn a leaden metropolis into a sustainable, robust utopia?

For some urban thinkers, the solution to all our current problems is to start again, from scratch. Songdo, in South Korea, is an example of the next generation of metropolis: a smart city, built according to the new rules of the Information Age. Built from reclaimed land 40 miles southwest of Seoul, it is a connected city, in which information is gathered and used to regulate the urban fabric. Buildings, objects, traffic lights are both sensors and activators. This type of city is no longer a static collection of places but "a computer in open air." It is a sentient place-a living and connected matrix in which buildings, signs, users and vehicles communicate with each other in real time.

Songdo's promotional brochure notes that the city appropriates the canals of Venice, Hong Kong's skyline, the park areas from Savanna Georgia and Napoleon's sense of street planning, and mixes it all up together. Beneath this architectural melee the city is wired with Cisco's proprietory U.City infrastructural software, meaning that Songdo can be run from a hub that functions as the city's "brain stem," gathering data from the sensors scattered throughout the city.

Street cameras watch the human flow to brighten the energy-saving street lamps that shut down when no one is around. Sensors surveil street traffic, collecting registration plate data to monitor congestion. Buildings, bridges and infrastructure are connected to avoid unexpected works or delays. On top of buildings, mini stations predict the weather, sending warnings when temperatures drop to a level that might cause a surge in energy use for heating. All waste, rubbish, energy use and water is metered and measured, offering potential ways to reduce inefficiencies.

Is this an efficiency dream? Or a control nightmare? It's hard to decide. The modernist era saw planned cities such as Braslia, Canberra and Chandrigarh, built from the dirt, as well as the more local post-war new town plans of Peterlee, Welwyn Garden City and Washington. Each was created as an expression of hope for the future-so what do smart cities tell us about ourselves?

In addition to Songdo, new cities are appearing everywhere. Masdar City has been created outside Abu Dhabi by Norman Foster as the first carbon-free city. In China there are numerous plans for eco-cities that harness information technology to make more sustainable environments. Often the techno-utopian claims made for such cities need to taken with a pinch of salt. Most of us will never live in cities created out of the desert. The prospective populations of these cities are minute compared to the majority of the global population that already lives within the dense, complex, and often straining-at-the-limits cities built from bricks, stones, steel and lives of the pre-Information Age. These cities face the challenge of adapting as best as possible to advances in technology even though they are poorly positioned to do so.

In November 2010, David Cameron announced the launch of Tech City, an initiative that hoped to turn a stretch of east London-from Shoreditch to Stratford-into the technology capital of Europe. The dilapidated post-industrial East End was to be transformed into a new gleaming smart hub: Silicon Roundabout, named after the Old Street roundabout. So did it work?

Within a year of Cameron's announcement, Tech City had attracted huge attention from international companies. The high profile push has raised the international standing of the project. For big tech companies looking for a place to site their European office, the publicity drive has worked. However, local start-ups have lost out, and with them has gone an important source of innovation. According to Elizabeth Varley, founder of TechHub, a hugely successful community workspace close by Old Street roundabout, the top-down initiative needs to be questioned. Around the roundabout itself there has been little investment: the tube station, one of the least attractive in the city, has not been improved. There has not even been an upgrade to the neighbourhood's broadband capacity. There are fears that the main effect of government cheerleading will be to raise rents.

According to Varley, the most urgent matter was the lack of government investment-but in the people rather than the place, with small grants "so that a young entrepreneur can eat for six months." A 2012 report by the Centre for London put the case for development from the ground-up rather than a policy to attract outside investment. The report concluded: "It has been evolving for years under the policy radar, and only now-as it reaches critical mass, and becomes the figurehead of London's digital economy-is it receiving much public attention... Tech City should be about taking what inner East London already has and helping it get even better."

Other British cities are adapting to new technology. In November 2012 Birmingham announced its Smart City Vision, which confronted precisely this challenge. Despite having the youngest population in the UK, 18.5 per cent of Birmingham's adult population still has no access to the internet. Overcoming this is the first step. Second, local government should become more efficient and find new ways to deliver services and share more between departments. There will also be a commitment to smart energy use, intelligent architecture and infrastructure planning-out with the old Victorian systems, in with the new.

The promise made by Birmingham's Smart City Vision was that: "Technology will be seamlessly interwoven into the fabric of our city life to provide better information, more choice, more convenience and less waste for our citizens, businesses, communities and public services."

The optimism and sense of ambition is laudable, as was the Victorian mission to provide clean water, sewers, and fresh air. But these plans are expensive. The installation of meters to measure energy and water usage has a price; there is no guarantee that "ultra fast digital connectivity" will attract "inward investment, create jobs and drive innovation." This "joined up, integrated and citizen-centric approach across city systems and processes, using and sharing real time data and intelligence" might lead to better decision making. But this is dependent on the quality of the people making the decisions, not just the size of the data set.

Amsterdam Smart City, launched in 2009. Like Birmingham, it is looking to upgrade its infrastructure. One lesson concerned the willingness of residents to take in the technological developments that were occurring around them. The lesson of Amsterdam is that citizens' tolerance for high-tech lectures from city officials is low.

Big schemes like this have to come from city hall, but they must be promoted with caution; both Birmingham and Amsterdam propose widespread top-down schemes that risk promising too much.

In addition, the intelligent city must not become a cage. The amount of security technology installed in London in advance of the 2012 Olympic was astounding. In Rio de Janeiro, in preparation for the 2014 World Cup, the city has worked with IBM to create an all-seeing information hub that collects data and could be the nerve centre during an emergency. It can also be used to watch and monitor the city from every angle.

Most of the major software companies have developed the proprietary code to make and market the future metropolis. Big players such as IBM, Cisco, Siemens, Phillips, and GE are entering the debate on the intelligent city. These big companies are talking to city halls, offering end-to-end solutions, the complete package to retrofit the everyday city for the 21st century.

Some of the most interesting ideas are coming from the MIT SENSEable Lab, run by the architect and designer Carlo Ratti. Ratti's team at MIT has looked at a number of projects that help the gathering together of huge sources of information that allow us to understand the city-not how we think it might work but how it actually, empirically functions. One project used small GPS monitors to find out where our trash ended up. Starting in Seattle, the team discovered that parts of the city's trash travelled thousands of miles, some items even crossing borders before being discarded.

Elsewhere, the Copenhagen Wheel, an attractively designed add-on to the back wheel of an ordinary bike, works both as a miniature engine that stores energy for those moments when you need a little help, and a multi-sensor that gathers data on your performance, traffic and air pollution. Simple devices like this could have as large an impact as the massive city-wide public infrastructure projects.

However, in the hope of developing the intelligent city, perhaps the most radical gesture is also the cheapest. City governments have been gathering data for decades; the use of information technology will make this easier, faster and bigger. But who owns this information? In 2009 Mayor Michael Bloomberg opened the New York City Open Data archive that made copious amounts of city data public. In 2010 Mayor Boris Johnson did the same in London; and since then has been followed by numerous cities around the world.

The datastore is not just a mechanism for transparency. While it is important that the city government proves itself to be open and accountable, establishing a sense of trust between the city and city hall, the variety of information being offered to general scrutiny has a far more valuable potential in engaging the active citizen. Once data is made available, city hall loses control on how that information is used, and by whom: hackers, activists, website designers, coders or app entrepreneurs. It can be utilised to start a political campaign or launch a new business.

This donation of the control of information by the traditional government powers to whoever has a broadband connection and a special interest is perhaps the start of the real intelligent city.

Leo Hollis is an urbanist and historian. His latest book is "Cities Are Good For You: the Genius of the Metropolis" (Bloomsbury)What does a citygain by becoming intelligent?

Rick Robinson

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:492M-MMS0-01J8-W12M-00000-00No Headline In Original2003-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisSECTION TO THE POINT; BUSINESS BRIEFS; NATIONAL EDITION; Pg. A02

BUILDING

Buffett may face rival Clayton bid

Though Clayton Homes doubts Cerberus Capital will actually make an offer, shares of the manufactured home builder rose 3% to $13.41. Shareholders were set to vote July 16 on a $1.7 bil, $12.50-per-share bid from Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. The founding Clayton family supports the bid, but some big shareholders call it too low.

** An online charity auction for a lunch date with billionaire investor Warren Buffett fetched $250,100, nearly eight times more than the previous highest price paid. He's been auctioning lunches since '00.

FINANCE

SEC probes Morgan Stanley sales

The agency started a formal investigation into the investment bank's mutual fund sales practices on April 29, Morgan Stanley said in a quarterly filing with the SEC. U.S. regulators in May said they were examining how brokerages sell mutual funds to investors.

** Prudential Securities on Thursday agreed to pay $382,000 to settle charges regarding its mutual fund sales oversight. The SEC said the case wasn't related to the broader fund sales probe.

Lawyers to whittle down IPO suits

A judge ordered both sides of a class-action suit over rigged stock offerings to pare the litigation to a more manageable 10-20 cases. The suit involves 55 investment banks, more than 300 firms and millions of pages of documents. Plaintiffs say banks manipulated IPO prices with rosy research and overcharged clients for access to hot IPOs.

Agency probes Freddie Mac CEO

The Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight is trying to find out if Greg Parseghian, the mortgage firm's new CEO, was involved in Freddie Mac's accounting problems, published reports said. Freddie Mac on June 25 said it'll restate results for '00, '01 and '02 upward by up to $4.5 bil.

BofA reorganizes debt business

Bank of America will create a debt operating committee to oversee three product groups to boost profit. The groups are investment-grade, asset-backed and mortgage-backed securities; treasuries, agencies, derivatives, commodities and foreign exchange; and leveraged debt and loans. It was No. 3 in global loan syndication in the 1st half, Thomson Financial said.

U.S. wants Quattrone trial in N.Y.

Fallen Credit Suisse First Boston star Frank Quattrone wants a trial in Calif. instead, saying that's where the alleged obstruction of justice and witness tampering took place. He may also get a more sympathetic jury there, where he's known as a big tech booster. Prosecutors say the change of venue would delay the trial and that all the witnesses can testify in N.Y.

** UBS' chief global strategist Ed Kerschner will leave the Swiss bank at year-end. Gary Gordon will replace him.

Q&A: Award Winning Movie Producer and Businessman Chad A. Verdi Discusses Hollywood Deals and Tech Investments in Apple and NXT-ID Inc.'s (OTCQB: NXTD) Wocket NEW YORK and POINT ROBERTS, Washington - May 19, 2014 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Verdi to Produce/Executive Produce Three Films with Oscar winning Director Martin Scorsese: Star studded actors include Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver "You may see a Wocket in a very famous Pocket" - C. Verdi Investorideas.com, a global news source covering leading topics and sectors including technology and entertainment, releases an exclusive Q&A with entrepreneurial movie producer, businessman and investor Chad A. Verdi of Rhode Island. Mr. Verdi discusses new and recent ventures including new movie deals and his investments in game-changing technologies, including Apple and biometric mobile security company NXT-ID Inc., (OTCQB: NXTD), which is currently preparing to launch its smart wallet, the Wocket™ (   www.wocketwallet.com), with advance orders starting May 28th. Mr. Verdi notes, "I am always looking ahead and I'm never satisfied with 'good enough', My goal is to partner with the best, hire the best talent and invest in leading edge companies.

Steve Jobs made Apple known for 'Think different', Richard Branson made his motto, 'Screw it , let's do it' and I live by 'Go big or go home'." Q&A Interview: Q: Investorideas.com This past year has already seen you reach some key milestones; making movies with the best in Hollywood, like Martin Scorsese and your investment in NXTD is up over 300 percent in less than a year. What are you most excited about for the balance of this year? A: Chad A. Verdi Well, that's a tough one. I guess I am the most excited about NXTD right now, only because they are about to launch the Wocket™ this month. Wocket™ is a smart wallet with a re-programmable single credit card device that operates under a secured system using biometrics. I feel it will change the way people make credit card payments worldwide. Everyone is trying to get in on this game with mobile payments, mobile wallets, mobile apps like LOOP and COIN. Everyone is trying to figure out the best way to do it. I think Wocket™ has the right approach; separate from your phone. Most people are concerned about what happens if they lose their phone or it gets stolen - what happens with all that payment info on your phone? With Wocket™, it's not a worry because after each transaction it basically goes back to a blank card. Your identity and payment info are safe! It's great to think I originally invested in this a few years ago and now it may become the leader in the payment sector that I thought it would! Q: Investorideas.com In terms of your investments, you invest in both large companies like Apple and Yahoo and other big tech and entertainment companies but you also take risks and invest in smaller companies with emerging technology like NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Where do you see the biggest potential pay-off? A: Chad A. Verdi I obviously wish I would have had the opportunity to get into Apple from the beginning. I would have bet big on it, just like I have with NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Companies that take a different path from what the competition is doing represent the biggest opportunity, if it works. Steve Jobs set the course for Apple, I still love the company but it's hard to know if the vision will stay intact. NXTD is still young and they are taking a revolutionary approach to payments and identity issues, very different from their competitors and I like that. In my opinion, I see a big risk/reward opportunity here today because they have a product that every consumer will want and currently needs. The Wocket™ can store over 10,000 credit cards/coupons, under a secured system. It's never been done before. If they are successful in delivering this product; the sky is the limit. They could be the next Apple and that is my second-largest holding. Q: Investorideas.com The company stated that they will launch the Wocket™ May 28th at the Plaza Hotel in New York and will be taking advance orders for the Wocket™ once the event is done. Will you be attending and will you be buying one once advance orders are opened up? A: Chad A. Verdi For sure I will be there supporting them and seeing first-hand how the Wocket™ is embraced. And of course, I will be buying many, many Wockets™! I will be giving them out to all of my actor and celebrity friends in Hollywood. Soon, you may see a Wocket™ in a very famous pocket! I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:555H-6CX1-DXXY-3480-00000-00No Headline In Original2012-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisA-SECTIONPg. A10Every ZoneOVERSIGHTEx-panel blasts tax break for AIG

Former members of a congressional panel that oversaw bailouts during the financial crisis blasted the Treasury Department on Monday for quietly granting a tax break worth billions to insurance giant American International Group.

The tax break amounts to a "stealth bailout" on top of the $182 billion that AIG received from the government, and it unfairly helps AIG, its shareholders and executives, former oversight panel chairman Elizabeth Warren and others said.

Warren, who also is a consumer advocate and Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate from Massachusetts, told reporters that tax breaks accounted for 90 percent of AIG profits last quarter. "We think it's time for Congress to end the special tax break," she said.

Companies sometimes defer losses and use them to reduce the tax burden in future years. Companies that change ownership usually face strict limits on how much of a loss they can defer. But Treasury granted AIG an exemption, handing the company $17.7 billion in profit, the former panel members said.

Damon Silvers, former vice chairman of the oversight panel, said the tax break unfairly benefits private AIG stockholders, including executives who were paid in stock options, at the expense of taxpayers.

"By doing it this way, substantial amounts of money leaked out to the benefit of private parties who really should not be benefiting from public policy in this way," Silvers said. He said the waiver gives AIG an unfair competitive advantage.

- Associated Press

LEGALYahoo sues Facebook over patents

Yahoo is filing a lawsuit against Facebook over patents, following through on a threat it made last month.

Yahoo said in a court filing Monday that Facebook has infringed 10 of its patents covering advertising, privacy controls and social networking.

Yahoo threatened to sue Facebook last month, insisting that the social network license its patents.

Facebook said it is disappointed in Yahoo and pledges to defend itself vigorously against what it calls "puzzling actions."

The patent claims could cast a spotlight on Facebook's vulnerabilities as it tries to complete an initial public offering of stock this spring. At the end of 2011, only 56 U.S. patents had been issued to Facebook - a relatively small number compared with other big tech companies.

- Associated Press

Also in Business

lYouku, owner of China's most- popular online video site, plans to acquire smaller competitor Tudou Holdings in a $1 billion stock deal that will help lower costs for licensing and transmitting content. The proposed deal will strengthen the new company's ability to compete with Baidu and Tencent Holdings in adding online video users in a nation where Google's YouTube is restricted. Youku and Tudou together accounted for more than a third of China's Web video advertising revenue last quarter, according to research company Analysys International.

lFederal safety regulators are investigating complaints that accelerators can stick in Ford Tauruses from model years 2005 and 2006. The investigation covers an estimated 360,000 of the sedans. So far, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has not ordered a recall.

lApple confirmed that it has run out of new iPad tablet computers available for pre-order on the Internet, with a message on Apple's online store telling customers that it will be two to three weeks before an iPad will arrive. So if you want to own the new iPad on the first day it's available, prepare to wait at an Apple Store.

lAn executive with the PayPal online payment service was struck and killed by a commuter train in Northern California. San Mateo County coroner's investigators on Sunday identified the victim as 39-year-old Eric Salvatierra of Palo Alto, vice president of online payment service PayPal, where he's worked for about five years.

- From news services

Coming Today

l8:30 a.m.: Retail sales report.

l2:15 p.m.: Announcement by Federal Reserve's policymaking Federal Open Market Committee.

lEarnings: German automaker BMW, Books-A-Million.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:4001-BFJ0-003M-X0HK-00000-00No Headline In Original2000-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisA; Pg. 24By Joseph Guinto, Investor's Business Daily

Congressman J.C. Watts, R-Okla., must have had deja vu on Monday. As he had done dozens of times while a star quarterback at the University of Oklahoma, Watts gathered teammates together, loaded them on a bus and sent them out to do battle. The team - a gaggle of GOP leaders - traveled from Capitol Hill to Virginia's tech-heavy Dulles corridor. The lawmakers visited companies there to see how they might help in the contest between cyber-criminals blitzing the Internet and cyber-security firms intent on blocking them. But for Watts, the deja vu ends there. For one thing, this is no game. The FBI says cybercrime costs companies and government $ 10 billion a year. And in a survey by the Computer Security Institute, 90% of companies polled said they've had a computer security breach in the last year. For another thing, the Internet industry's top firms have told federal legislators something Watts' coach, Barry Switzer, never imagined saying: "Ride the bench." Despite recent high-profile attacks in which hackers hobbled major sites like EBay and Yahoo, big tech companies haven't haven't embraced stronger cybercrime laws. "I do think we already have sufficient laws" to deal with cyber-security, said Michael Hershman, head of Decision Strategies Fairfax International, a security consulting firm. Some sound a more strident tone. Officials from Microsoft and Cisco Systems recently told a joint House-Senate panel on cybercrime that the industry can take care of itself. Howard Schmidt, Microsoft's chief information security officer, cautioned against any "unnecessary outside regulation or interference in the operation of dynamic, very productive businesses.

"Infrastructure security does not lend itself to government management," he said. The White House heard the same line when it brought 20 Internet industry executives together with academics and government officials just after major hacking attacks in February. After the meeting, White House officials said the industry representatives didn't ask for new legislation to fight back against hackers. When you consider the numbers, the industry's reluctance to pursue cyber-criminals seems funny. Cybercrime already has a broad impact. Just one prominent example, the Melissa virus of 1999, caused $ 80 million in damage worldwide. In a December incident, 300,000 credit card numbers were pulled from the databanks at CD Universe and posted on the Web. And the problem is expected to get worse. As more Internet users connect through high-speed modems such as cable and DSL lines, they'll be on the Net nearly nonstop. This will give hackers thousands more computers whose data they can dip into or whose Internet links they can exploit to commit crimes. The attackers are as varied as the crimes. Some are disgruntled employees looking to sabotage systems. Some are criminals looking to steal data and hold it for ransom. And some are teen-agers vandalizing a site for fun or cracking a company's security to expose its flaws. That vast potential number of cyber-attackers makes preventing cyberattacks almost impossible. The National Computer Security Center says 64% of U.S. corporations, government agencies and universities have already been victims of cybercrime. That's made fighting off attacks a 24-hour job for some. Like many of its members, the National Association of Securities Dealers says its Nasdaq.com Web pages are under constant assault. "We have 20 to 30 hacks ongoing at any given time," said Larry Bickner, vice president of information security for the association. Its response: more and more security programs to catch as many hackers as possible before they can do any damage. Given the rising costs, why haven't companies sought more government help in nabbing hackers? Some credit Silicon Valley's laissez-faire leanings. But there may be other concerns. "Companies just want to recover as much money as they can and slap the person on the wrist and get it over with," said Chuck Bowe, a risk management expert at KPMG. "They don't want to take action against the people they catch, because their customers will flee over the publicity." Indeed, the FBI says only 17% of the victims of cybercrime report the crimes committed against them. There's good reason to worry about bad publicity. When E-Trade Group, EBay, Buy.com and Amazon.com were among those hit in February, it made news across the country. Competitors know this, so they use hacking incidents against each other. When Russian mobsters pilfered $ 10 million from Citibank last year, the competition played it up. And they did so even though Citibank got back virtually all of the money. In addition to bad publicity from a public hunt for cyber-criminals, there's also a morass of private data issues to be considered. Among them: Should an Internet Service Provider open its logs to federal investigators? Will client confidentiality be compromised if the FBI checks through an e-commerce site's files? For now the industry seems content to take its chances. Harris Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America, told Congress the industry has "reservations about working too closely with the federal law enforcement and national security community and has concerns about jeopardizing business concerns by sharing information on security issues." Clearly the industry has reason to be concerned about federal intervention in cyber-security. While nearly all of the Net's infrastructure is private, government agencies use it a lot. Nearly 25% of all computers sold each year, for instance, go to government agencies. That risk helped lead the GOP team to the Dulles corridor Monday, and has led other lawmakers and agencies to propose beefed-up security measures. Among them: Several senators and representatives are backing proposals to create a federal clearinghouse for sharing information on cyberattacks. The clearinghouse would be protected against Freedom of Information requests and privacy liability. The FBI is doubling its force of digital investigators. It plans to have cybercrime units in all of its 56 field offices within two years. The Clinton administration wants $ 91 million for new technologies to combat cyber-terrorism. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison, R-Texas, is pushing a bill to double penalties for serious hacking offenses to 10 years in prison for the first offense and 20 for a second offense. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and others have introduced bills to give the FBI and other federal agencies more powers to investigate cybercrime around the world. Other initiatives would let federal investigators and prosecutors begin their work at the beginning of a hacking case. Under current law, you have to show more than $ 5,000 in damages before federal prosecution can start. Even with all the new proposals, federal officials have made it clear that they think private industry will have to look after itself. Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder told a joint House-Senate cyber-security panel that "we in government will not be able to solve all these problems. We believe the private sector should take the lead in protecting private computer networks." Alan Paller, a director at the SANS Institute, a research group linking nearly 100,000 computer managers and security professionals, hopes to do just that. SANS is promoting through its Web site free security tools that help prevent the kind of hacking that shut down Yahoo and crippled EBay, E-Trade and Amazon.com in February. While such measures aren't new, major Internet companies have been slow to adopt them because of cost.

A NAVY HELICOPTER SPOTTED THE FIVE MEN IN INTERNATIONAL WATERS WAVING A MAKESHIFT FLARE AFTER THEIR BOAT STARTED TAKING ON WATER. THE 'U-S-S MCCAMPBELL' LAUNCHED BOATS TO RESCUE THE FISHERMEN AND BROUGHT THEM TO MANILA TODAY. THEY'RE SAID TO BE IN GOOD HEALTH. THE GUIDED- MISSILE DESTROYER IS IN THE PHILIPPINES AS PART OF A GOODWILL VISIT BY THE U-S-S GEORGE WASHINGTON AIRCRAFT CARRIER STRIKE GROUP. THE IPAD-MINI IS OUT - NOW WAIT FOR THE NEXT BIG TECH LAUNCH - WINDOWS EIGHT. HOWARD DICUS HAS YOUR TECH NEWS. WINDOWS EIGHT COMES OUT THIS WEEK AND MICROSOFT'S FUTURE DEPENDS ON IT. THIS IS THE WINDOWS VERSION THAT IS SUPPOSED TO POWER TABLETS AND MOBILE DEVICES. ZD NET CALLS THE LAUNCH A BINARY EVENT - IT'LL THRIVE OR DIVE. AND ITS TESTERS SAY IT NOT THAT INTUITIVE. THEY SAY IT WORKS WELL ON A TABLET BUT CAN BE ANNOYING ON A PC. MICROSOFT ALSO FACES TROUBLE FROM EUROPE. REGULATORS SAY IT PROMISED A WEB BROWER CHOICE FOR WINDOWS EIGHT BUT DIDN'T. IN OTHER TECH NEWS - THE IPAD-MINI COSTS MORE THAN PREDICTED - STARTING AT 329 DOLLARS - BUT HAS BETTER FEATURES THAN EXPECTED - J.P. MORGAN FORECASTS IT WILL TAKE SALES EVEN FROM RIVAL TABLETS THAT COST LESS - BUT OTHER COMMENTATORS ARE SAYING MILLIONS OF CONSUMERS ALREADY HAVE ALL THE DEVICES THEY NEED, AND THE NOOK H-D HAS A BETTER DISPLAY. AT&T ACTIVATED SIX MILLION SMARTPHONES OVER THE SUMMER - AND HOW MANY OF THEM WERE APPLE IPHONES? SEVENTY-SEVEN PERCENT OF THEM. BAD TIMES IN THE GAME BIZ - NINTENDO CUTS ITS FULL YEAR PROFIT FORECAST 70 PERCENT ON WEAK SALES AND A STRONG YEN - SONY HAS A DIFFERENT KIND OF SETBACK - HACKERS RELEASE DECRYPTION KEYS FOR PLAYSTATION THREE. THEY CAN ZOOM IN NICE AND TIGHT ON YOUR HOUSE... AND ROAM AROUND THE DEPTHS OF THE SEA. AND ROAM AROUND THE DEPTHS OF THE SEA. NOW GOOGLE... IS GOING HIKING. AND JUST IN TIME FOR HALLOWEEN... A REAL-LIFE WITCH STORY. WHAT'S TRENDING IS NEXT. LET'S CHECK OUT ONE OF OUR MORNING HOT SPOTS... STICK AROUND -- YOU'RE WATCHING SUNRISE ON KGMB AND KNHL. Q&A: Award Winning Movie Producer and Businessman Chad A. Verdi Discusses Hollywood Deals and Tech Investments in Apple and NXT-ID Inc.'s (OTCQB: NXTD) Wocket NEW YORK and POINT ROBERTS, Washington - May 19, 2014 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Verdi to Produce/Executive Produce Three Films with Oscar winning Director Martin Scorsese: Star studded actors include Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver "You may see a Wocket in a very famous Pocket" - C. Verdi Investorideas.com, a global news source covering leading topics and sectors including technology and entertainment, releases an exclusive Q&A with entrepreneurial movie producer, businessman and investor Chad A. Verdi of Rhode Island. Mr. Verdi discusses new and recent ventures including new movie deals and his investments in game-changing technologies, including Apple and biometric mobile security company NXT-ID Inc., (OTCQB: NXTD), which is currently preparing to launch its smart wallet, the Wocket™ (   www.wocketwallet.com), with advance orders starting May 28th. Mr. Verdi notes, "I am always looking ahead and I'm never satisfied with 'good enough', My goal is to partner with the best, hire the best talent and invest in leading edge companies.

Steve Jobs made Apple known for 'Think different', Richard Branson made his motto, 'Screw it , let's do it' and I live by 'Go big or go home'." Q&A Interview: Q: Investorideas.com This past year has already seen you reach some key milestones; making movies with the best in Hollywood, like Martin Scorsese and your investment in NXTD is up over 300 percent in less than a year. What are you most excited about for the balance of this year? A: Chad A. Verdi Well, that's a tough one. I guess I am the most excited about NXTD right now, only because they are about to launch the Wocket™ this month. Wocket™ is a smart wallet with a re-programmable single credit card device that operates under a secured system using biometrics. I feel it will change the way people make credit card payments worldwide. Everyone is trying to get in on this game with mobile payments, mobile wallets, mobile apps like LOOP and COIN. Everyone is trying to figure out the best way to do it. I think Wocket™ has the right approach; separate from your phone. Most people are concerned about what happens if they lose their phone or it gets stolen - what happens with all that payment info on your phone? With Wocket™, it's not a worry because after each transaction it basically goes back to a blank card. Your identity and payment info are safe! It's great to think I originally invested in this a few years ago and now it may become the leader in the payment sector that I thought it would! Q: Investorideas.com In terms of your investments, you invest in both large companies like Apple and Yahoo and other big tech and entertainment companies but you also take risks and invest in smaller companies with emerging technology like NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Where do you see the biggest potential pay-off? A: Chad A. Verdi I obviously wish I would have had the opportunity to get into Apple from the beginning. I would have bet big on it, just like I have with NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Companies that take a different path from what the competition is doing represent the biggest opportunity, if it works. Steve Jobs set the course for Apple, I still love the company but it's hard to know if the vision will stay intact. NXTD is still young and they are taking a revolutionary approach to payments and identity issues, very different from their competitors and I like that. In my opinion, I see a big risk/reward opportunity here today because they have a product that every consumer will want and currently needs. The Wocket™ can store over 10,000 credit cards/coupons, under a secured system. It's never been done before. If they are successful in delivering this product; the sky is the limit. They could be the next Apple and that is my second-largest holding. Q: Investorideas.com The company stated that they will launch the Wocket™ May 28th at the Plaza Hotel in New York and will be taking advance orders for the Wocket™ once the event is done. Will you be attending and will you be buying one once advance orders are opened up? A: Chad A. Verdi For sure I will be there supporting them and seeing first-hand how the Wocket™ is embraced. And of course, I will be buying many, many Wockets™! I will be giving them out to all of my actor and celebrity friends in Hollywood. Soon, you may see a Wocket™ in a very famous pocket! I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. Verdi Music and Talent Supervisor Media Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4090091About InvestorIdeas.com: InvestorIdeas.com is a global news source covering leading sectors including biotech stocks tech and mobile stocks, mining, energy, waters stocks, renewable energy stocks, beverage stocks and more. urn:contentItem:57MC-0VH1-JCM7-R0KX-00000-00No Headline In Original2013-01-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisMONEYPg. 6D

U.S. stocks meandered between small gains and losses Monday, cooling off after a rally that had pushed the Standard & Poor's 500 index above 1,500 for the first time since December 2007. Encouraging news about manufacturing provided an early boost, but stocks fell later after a report on the pace of home sales fell short of expectations.

The Dow closed down 14.05 points, or 0.1 percent, at 13,881.93. The S&P 500 fell 2.78, or 0.2 percent, to 1,500.18. The Nasdaq composite index added 4.59, or 0.2 percent, to 3,154.

The government said before trading began that orders for long-lasting goods rose in December by 4.6 percent, helped by a 10 percent gain in orders for new aircraft. The report was a sign of strength for the manufacturing sector, a crucial driver of economic growth.

Heavy equipment maker Caterpillar said separately that its fourth-quarter net income exceeded analysts' expectations, after adjusting for the cost of a soured deal to buy a Chinese maker of roofing supports for mines. Caterpillar said it took a big charge in the quarter because the Chinese company had misrepresented its finances.

Caterpillar Inc. said it expects growth in China to improve without regaining the levels seen in 2010 or 2011. The stock was the biggest gainer in the Dow Jones industrial average, closing up $1.87, or 2 percent, at $97.45.

The Dow Jones transportation index edged higher, notching its tenth straight increase and its twelfth gain in the past 13 trading days.

The National Association of Realtors said that its index of pending home sales fell in December.

- Associated Press

suggesting that sales of previously occupied homes may slow in the coming months. The report, which was weaker than many economists had expected, helped push stocks lower for much of the morning. They were roughly flat by midday, and spent the afternoon swapping small bumps and dips.

The Dow and the S&P 500 are rapidly approaching their all-time closing highs, reached on Oct. 9, 2007. The Dow is about 282 points below its high of 14,164.53; the S&P 500 is 65 points shy of its record of 1,565.

Economic data may be less likely to boost the indexes because traders have become harder to impress as the data have strengthened in recent weeks, said Bill Stone, chief investment strategist with PNC Asset Management Group.

"Before, even if you came in just at expectations, that was like a victory," he said. Because of the market's recent upturn, he said, "you get less of a pop for just making the numbers."

Among companies in the S&P 500 that reported earnings Monday, Biogen Idec Inc. said its fourth-quarter net income slipped nearly 3 percent because of a tax charge and higher expenses. Still, the biotech drug maker rose $3.79, or 2.6 percent, to $149.99.

Roper Industries Inc., which makes medical and industrial equipment, said its fourth-quarter net income rose 18 percent. But the company issued mixed guidance for the current quarter and full year 2013. It fell 33 cents to $118.50.

Oil company Hess Inc. was the biggest gainer in the S&P 500, adding 6.1 percent after the company said it plans to sell its U.S. terminal network, shutter its New Jersey refinery and continue shifting its focus to exploration and production. Hess also said that the hedge fund Elliott Associates plans to seek regulatory approval to buy a major stake in the company. Hess rose $3.58 to $62.48.

Several big tech companies reported their results after the market closed and saw big price swings in after-hours trading:

- Web portal Yahoo Inc. rose 81 cents, or 4 percent, to $21.12 after saying its fourth-quarter earnings topped analyst estimates as an upturn in its international investments helped end a three-year revenue slump.

- Hard disk maker Seagate Technology PLC said it beat analysts' estimates in its results for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 28. It rose 69 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $38.10 after hours.

- Cloud computing provider VMWare Inc. said its net income edged higher, but the company announced guidance that was far weaker than analysts had expected. VMWare lost $10.83, or 11 percent, to $87.49 after hours.

Strong corporate earnings helped push the S&P 500 through the 1,500 milestone Friday after several calm, relatively news-free weeks. In addition to companies' performance, traders have been encouraged by signals that housing market is improving steadily and hiring is picking up, albeit slowly.

There will plenty of fresh data to drive trading this week, including retail sales, economic growth and the government's report on hiring and employment in January, which is due out Friday. More than one-fifth of the companies in the S&P 500 will report fourth-quarter earnings this week.

Stone said stocks are trading sideways in part because many investors are awaiting economic reports later this week, especially the employment report. There is agreement among economists and analysts that the economy slowed in the fourth quarter, he said, and this week's numbers will help answer the question of "how slow, and how much did it impact employment."

The yield in the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 1.97 percent from 1.95 percent late Friday, reflecting lower demand for ultra-safe investments. After Monday's factory orders report, the yield rose briefly above 2 percent for the first time since April. A bond's yield rises as demand for it decreases.

WELCOME BACK. OVERSEAS INVESTORS HAD A PROFITABLE DAY IN ASIA BUT IN EUROPE, THEY ARE ENCOURAGED BY THE UPWARD TREND IN U.S. MARKETS. AT THE SAME TIME DETROIT IS SELLING CARS AGAIN AND IT HAS THE GOVERNMENT TO THANK, IMAGINE THAT. CHRIS COTTER FROM FOX BUSINESS NEWS HAS DETAILS LIVE FROM NEW YORK.

GOOD MORNING. >> GOOD MORNING. >> GOOD MORNING. >> SO. LET'S GET INTO THE, THE CASH FOR CLUNKERS THIS MORNING. THE SENATE IS, IS STILL DEBATING ITS MERITS BUT DETROIT, YOU KNOW, SAID TO BE PRETTY HAPPY. THE ADMINISTRATION WANTS TO CLEAR OUT THE INVENTORY, BUT, IS THIS, IS THIS GOING TO JUMPSTART CAR PRODUCTION? >> THAT'S THE BIG THING. WE HAVE TODAY TO GET IT DONE, THE SENATE HAS TO APPROVE AN ADDITIONAL $2 BILLION, OTHERWISE, THE PROGRAM COMES TO A COMPLETE HALT, AND THAT TALK OF, THE INCREASING PRODUCTION OR FORGETTING PRODUCTION STARTED EARLIER THAN WE ORIGINALLY THOUGHT GOES OUT THE WINDOW. AND BECAUSE, YOU KNOW, THIS SHOWS THE DOMINO EFFECT OF, OF, YOU KNOW, STIMULUS HERE, THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY. A LOT OF PEOPLE QUESTION WHETHER IT'S WORTH IT OR WHETHER WE WANT GOVERNMENT SPENDING. IT'S ROBBING PETER TO PAY PAUL. TAKING SOME OF THE 187 BILLION APPROVED AND TAKING IT FROM SOMEWHERE ELSE AND PUTTING IT TOWARDS THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY HERE, AND IT WORKS. THERE IS A DOMINO EFFECT GOING BACK TO SUPPLIERS, UPSTREAM, DOWNSTREAM TO THE DEALERSHIPS, AND THEY ARE ALL, ALL BENEFITING FROM IT, AND, AND, YOU KNOW, IT'S THAT MULTIPLIER EFFECT WITH THE DOLLAR. IT'S WORKING, WE'RE GOING TO SEE INCREASED PRODUCTION ACROSS THE BOARD, AND WE HAVE INVENTORY THAT HAS BEEN WORKING DOWN, ESPECIALLY AT CHRYSLER. CHRYSLER WAS MATCHING THE 4500 FOR THE FIRST WEEK, AND THEN THEY SAID WE CAN'T DO IT ANY MORE BECAUSE WE'RE RUNNING OUT OF CARS SO THAT WILL RAMP UP BUILDING NEW STARS AND WILL BENEFIT EVERYBODY, ALL THE WAY THROUGHOUT THE CHAIN. >> YEP. >> SO. THAT'S WHY IT'S SUCH IS A POSITIVE THING. I DON'T KNOW IF YOU AGREE WITH GOVERNMENT SPENDING TO AID IN THE STIMULUS BUT IF YOU DO, THIS IS AS GOOD OF A PLACE TO SPEND THAT MONEY AS ANY. >> THERE ARE MORE FUEL FINGER CARS ON THE ROAD AND HOPEFULLY, MORE WILL BE PRODUCED OUT OF THIS. ALL RIGHT, LET'S TALK ABOUT THE MARKETS. IT WAS -- >> NO QUESTION ABOUT IT. >> IT WAS A MIX IN ASIA AND EUROPE, AND THE FUTURES POINT TO A SLOW OPENING BELL. >> OUR FUTURES ARE DOWN A BIT. THAT MAKES SENSE BECAUSE WHAT WE HAVE HAD IS, IS THIS RUN, AND EVEN YESTERDAY, UP OVER 1,000 ON THE S&P 500, AROUND 150 AND POINTS UP ON THE DOW. YOU ARE GOING TO GET A PULLBACK, AND IT'S HEALTHYING TO THAT BECAUSE IF YOU DON'T, WHAT YOU HAVE IS, IS UP IN A STRAIGHT LINE AND OFF A CLIFF. WE DON'T WANT THAT. HOW ABOUT A LITTLE, A COUPLE DAYS TO, TO TAKE A BREATH AND REEVALUATE A BIT AND THEN THAT NEXT LEG UP, THAT'S A HEALTHY MARKET, AND SO, YOU KIND OF, YOU GET THE FEELING THAT THERE IS MORE BULLISH SENTIMENT BUT YOU NEED THE PULLBACK SO THEY WILL START, PROBABLY IN A NEGATIVE TERRITORY. >> THERE IS A FALLING OUT BETWEEN GOOGLE AND APPLE. GOOGLE C.E.O. ERIK SCHMIDT HAS RESIGNED, WE UNDERSTAND, FROM, FROM THE BOARD OF APPLE, AND THIS COMES AS APPLE BANNED GOOGLE APPLICATIONS FROM THE I-PHONE. IT SOUNDS LIKE THERE IS A LOT MORE TO THIS THAN JUST THE, THE I-PHONE APPS ISSUE. >> WELL, YEAH. THERE ARE A COUPLE OF BIG THINGS. YOU MENTIONED, GOOGLE'S C.E.O. HAS BEEN ON THE APPLE BOARD FOR THE LAST THREE YEARS, AND HE RESIGNED, A MUTUAL THING. FIRST, THERE ARE REGULATORS THAT, THAT ARE KIND OF NOT SNOOPING AROUND BUT LOOKING AT THE SITUATION WHERE THERE MIGHT BE SOME, SOME COLLUSIVE ISSUES WITH, WITH HAVING THE, THE C.E.O. OF ONE MASSIVELY BIG TECH COMPANY ON THE BOARD OF ANOTHER MASSIVELY BIG COMPANY. THE OTHER THING IS, GOOGLE AND DOING A LOT OF THINGS OF APPLE. SO YOU WOULD HAVE TO HAVE SITUATIONS WHERE ERIK SCHULTZ WOULD STEP OUT OF THE ROOM IN BOARD MEETINGS BECAUSE THERE WAS COMPETITIVE, YOU KNOW, ISSUES THERE SO, IT DOES MAKE SENSE THAT GOOGLE IS DOING A LOT WITH THE

STATION: CNBC
USA

>>> WE KNOW FULL WELL ABOUT THE PROBLEMS AT BEAR STEARNS,MERRILL LYNCH AND CITI AND THE NEXT SHOE TO DROP MAY IN FACT BE LEHMAN BROTHERS. ON-AIR EDITOR CHARLIE GASPARINO JOINS US FROM NEW YORK WITH MORE. >> HOW ARE YOU DOING, BRIAN. >> WE ALSO KNOW FULL WELL ABOUT THE PROBLEMS IN THE SUBPRIME MORTGAGE MARKET AND THAT'S CAUSING ISSUES AT CITIGROUP, AT BEAR STEARNSAND MERRILL LYNCH AND MORGAN STANLEY, BUT THE OTHER SHOE TO DROP AT LEAST WHEN YOU TALK TO ANALYSTS OUT THERE IS THE COMMERCIAL MORTGAGE-BACKED MARKET AND PARTICULARLY IF YOU THINK WE'LL HAVE A RECESSION IN THE NEW YEAR AND THAT IS WHAT I HEAR PUTS LEHMAN BROTHERS CLEARLY IN THE CROSSHAIRS.

ALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS LOOK AT THE TOP UNDERWRITERS OF COMMERCIAL MORTGAGE BACKED OBLIGATIONS AND MORTGAGE-BACKED SECURITIES AND YOU SEE LEHMAN AT $115 BILLION APPROXIMATE, MORGAN STANLEY, 93, BEAR STEARNS, 86, JP MORGAN, 80, AND GOLDMAN SACHS, AND I THREW IN WACHOVIA WITH $29 BILLION. I'LL TELL TELL YOU WHY IN A MINUTE, BUT LEHMAN BROTHERS, FROM WHAT I UNDERSTAND, HOLDS $40 BILLION OF THOSE SECURITIES ON ITS BOOKS. HERE YOU SEE LEHMAN BROTHERS TRADING OFF WITH A LOT OF THE OTHER FINANCIALS AND THAT, I HEAR, COULD BE A PROBLEM FOR LEHMAN GOING FORWARD. A LOT OF ANALYSTS SAY THAT WHEN THAT MARKET STARTS TO TEETER, I DON'T THINK IT WILL BE AS BAD AS THE SUBPRIME MARKET AND THAT'S WHEN LEHMAN WHICH HAS ESCAPED ALL THIS, THAT'S WHEN LEHMAN COULD BE IN THE CROSSHAIRS AS WELL. IT'S NOT AS BAD AS SUBPRIME. COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE IS A SURER MARKET, BUT IF WE DO HAVE A RECESSION, LEHMAN BROTHERSES WILL TAKE IT ON THE CHIN WITH THESE. >> ONE OTHER THING, CHARLIE. WAS BOB RUBIN HAVING LUNCH WITH CHUCK PRINCE YESTERDAY? WHAT WERE THEY TALKING ABOUT? >> FROM WHAT I HEAR THEY WERE HAVING LUNCH AT THE FOUR SEASONS. I PREFER SAN PIETRO, I GUESS THEY STAY AWAY FROM MY SPIES, OR THEY THINK THEY DO AT THE FOUR SEASONS. THEY WERE PROBABLY TALKING ABOUT THE WRITEDOWN WHICH I HEAR WILL HAPPEN ON WEDNESDAY. THEY'LL ANNOUNCE ALL THIS STUFF AND THE REAL QUESTION IS HOW BIG IS THE WRITEDOWN AND WILL THIS LEAD TO LAYOFFS? FROM WHAT I HEAR THE WRITEDOWN WILL BE HUGE. THEY'LL ANNOUNCE SOMETHING LIKE $24 BILLION. THAT'S AN UNCONFIRMED NUMBER, BUT THAT'S WHAT THE SPECULATION IS INTERNALLY AND THE OTHER SPECULATION IS WHAT ARE THEY GOING DO WITH LAYOFFS AND I THINK THAT'S A WILD CARD. I THINK, CLEARLY, MIDDLE MANAGERS HAVE BEEN TOLD AND WE REPORTED THIS EARLY, COME UP WITH LAYOFFS SOMEWHERE IN THE 5 TO 10% RANGE OF CITIGROUP'S 370,000 PEOPLE, BUT THE QUESTION IS DO THEY ACTUALLY TAKE THAT? I THINK THERE'S DEBATE INTERNALLY WHETHER THEY WANT TO DO THE WHOLE THING BECAUSE THEY WANT TO MAINTAIN THE MODEL. >> ALL RIGHT. ALSO, QUICKLY, WE'VE SEEN ALLEN SCHWARTZ'S FIRST COMMENTS OVER BEAR STEARNS, IF THERE'S A PLAY FOR BEAR, WHO MIGHT NUMBER PLAY? >> LISTEN, THIS IS COMPLETELY SPECULATION. I'M GETTING THIS THREE STEPS REMOVED. TO BREAK THIS STORY YOU HAVE TO SPEAK MANDARIN CHINESE, I BARELY SPEAK EDGE HEAR/, DON'T CAN ME TO SPEAK MANDARIN CHINESE. I HEAR SENIOR PEOPLE IN CITIC HAVE BEEN TALKING ABOUT BUYING A BIGGER STAKE, MAYBE BUYING ALL OF BEAR STEARNSAND THERE ARE A LOT OF POLITICAL AND HURDLES TO JUMP THROUGH, BUT IT MAKES SENSE ON A COUPLE OF LEVELS. NUMBER ONE, NO U.S. BANK WOULD TOUCH BEAR STEARNSIN ITS STATE. IT'S GOT A HUGE PROBLEM HERE IN TERMS OF THE BUSINESS MODEL. I THINK EUROPEAN BANKS WOULD BE SKEPTICAL AS WELL. WHY GO FOR THE FIRM THAT'S THE MOST IN TROUBLE, BUT THE CHINESE OBVIOUSLY WANT TO BUY A U.S. INVESTMENT BANK. THEY HAVE A FOOTHOLD IN BEAR STEARNS. THEY MAY ROLL THE DICE WITH THIS COMPANY WHICH IS OBVIOUSLY IN BAD SHAPE. >> CHARLIE, THANKS A LOT. WE'LL SEE WHAT REGULATORS HAVE TO STAY ABOUT THAT. CHARLIE GASPARINO. SUE'S LET'S SEND IT TO YOU. >> WE'D LOVE TO HAVE MR. PRINCE AND MR. RUBIN JOIN US FUR LUNCH IN THE FOUR SEASONS WHEN WE DO OUR SHOW THERE. THAT WOULD BE GREAT. FEEL FREE TO HAVE LUNCH AGAIN, GENTLEMEN AND COME ON OUR SHOW. MEANTIME, AS YOU KNOW, HUNDREDS OF DEALS HAVE BEEN MADE THIS WEEK AT THE CONSUMER ELECTRONICS SHOW IN LAS VEGSA. IT'S WHERE SMALL BUSINESS MEETS OPPORTUNITY WHERE THE GADGETS OF TODAY HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO BECOME THE BIG TECH COMPANIES OF TOMORROW. TONIGHT'S SPECIAL, BIG IDEA, IT'S THE INSIDER'S GUIDE TO SUCCESS. THE GRAND FINALE OF THE MEGA ROAD TO CES SERIES THAT DONNY HAS BEEN DOING. TONIGHT WATCH AS FOUR PIONEERING ENTREPRENEURS FIND OUT IF THEY WILL BE THE NEXT GREAT TECH COMPANY. >> HOW DO YOU THINK THE MEETING WENT? >> DONNY, I THOUGHT THE MEETING WAS TERRIFIC.
