Q&A: Award Winning Movie Producer and Businessman Chad A. Verdi Discusses Hollywood Deals and Tech Investments in Apple and NXT-ID Inc.'s (OTCQB: NXTD) Wocket NEW YORK and POINT ROBERTS, Washington - May 19, 2014 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Verdi to Produce/Executive Produce Three Films with Oscar winning Director Martin Scorsese: Star studded actors include Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver "You may see a Wocket in a very famous Pocket" - C. Verdi Investorideas.com, a global news source covering leading topics and sectors including technology and entertainment, releases an exclusive Q&A with entrepreneurial movie producer, businessman and investor Chad A. Verdi of Rhode Island. Mr. Verdi discusses new and recent ventures including new movie deals and his investments in game-changing technologies, including Apple and biometric mobile security company NXT-ID Inc., (OTCQB: NXTD), which is currently preparing to launch its smart wallet, the Wocket™ (   www.wocketwallet.com), with advance orders starting May 28th. Mr. Verdi notes, "I am always looking ahead and I'm never satisfied with 'good enough', My goal is to partner with the best, hire the best talent and invest in leading edge companies.

Steve Jobs made Apple known for 'Think different', Richard Branson made his motto, 'Screw it , let's do it' and I live by 'Go big or go home'." Q&A Interview: Q: Investorideas.com This past year has already seen you reach some key milestones; making movies with the best in Hollywood, like Martin Scorsese and your investment in NXTD is up over 300 percent in less than a year. What are you most excited about for the balance of this year? A: Chad A. Verdi Well, that's a tough one. I guess I am the most excited about NXTD right now, only because they are about to launch the Wocket™ this month. Wocket™ is a smart wallet with a re-programmable single credit card device that operates under a secured system using biometrics. I feel it will change the way people make credit card payments worldwide. Everyone is trying to get in on this game with mobile payments, mobile wallets, mobile apps like LOOP and COIN. Everyone is trying to figure out the best way to do it. I think Wocket™ has the right approach; separate from your phone. Most people are concerned about what happens if they lose their phone or it gets stolen - what happens with all that payment info on your phone? With Wocket™, it's not a worry because after each transaction it basically goes back to a blank card. Your identity and payment info are safe! It's great to think I originally invested in this a few years ago and now it may become the leader in the payment sector that I thought it would! Q: Investorideas.com In terms of your investments, you invest in both large companies like Apple and Yahoo and other big tech and entertainment companies but you also take risks and invest in smaller companies with emerging technology like NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Where do you see the biggest potential pay-off? A: Chad A. Verdi I obviously wish I would have had the opportunity to get into Apple from the beginning. I would have bet big on it, just like I have with NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Companies that take a different path from what the competition is doing represent the biggest opportunity, if it works. Steve Jobs set the course for Apple, I still love the company but it's hard to know if the vision will stay intact. NXTD is still young and they are taking a revolutionary approach to payments and identity issues, very different from their competitors and I like that. In my opinion, I see a big risk/reward opportunity here today because they have a product that every consumer will want and currently needs. The Wocket™ can store over 10,000 credit cards/coupons, under a secured system. It's never been done before. If they are successful in delivering this product; the sky is the limit. They could be the next Apple and that is my second-largest holding. Q: Investorideas.com The company stated that they will launch the Wocket™ May 28th at the Plaza Hotel in New York and will be taking advance orders for the Wocket™ once the event is done. Will you be attending and will you be buying one once advance orders are opened up? A: Chad A. Verdi For sure I will be there supporting them and seeing first-hand how the Wocket™ is embraced. And of course, I will be buying many, many Wockets™! I will be giving them out to all of my actor and celebrity friends in Hollywood. Soon, you may see a Wocket™ in a very famous pocket! I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. Q&A: Award Winning Movie Producer and Businessman Chad A. Verdi Discusses Hollywood Deals and Tech Investments in Apple and NXT-ID Inc.'s (OTCQB: NXTD) Wocket NEW YORK and POINT ROBERTS, Washington - May 19, 2014 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Verdi to Produce/Executive Produce Three Films with Oscar winning Director Martin Scorsese: Star studded actors include Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver "You may see a Wocket in a very famous Pocket" - C. Verdi Investorideas.com, a global news source covering leading topics and sectors including technology and entertainment, releases an exclusive Q&A with entrepreneurial movie producer, businessman and investor Chad A. Verdi of Rhode Island. Mr. Verdi discusses new and recent ventures including new movie deals and his investments in game-changing technologies, including Apple and biometric mobile security company NXT-ID Inc., (OTCQB: NXTD), which is currently preparing to launch its smart wallet, the Wocket™ (   www.wocketwallet.com), with advance orders starting May 28th. Mr. Verdi notes, "I am always looking ahead and I'm never satisfied with 'good enough', My goal is to partner with the best, hire the best talent and invest in leading edge companies.

Steve Jobs made Apple known for 'Think different', Richard Branson made his motto, 'Screw it , let's do it' and I live by 'Go big or go home'." Q&A Interview: Q: Investorideas.com This past year has already seen you reach some key milestones; making movies with the best in Hollywood, like Martin Scorsese and your investment in NXTD is up over 300 percent in less than a year. What are you most excited about for the balance of this year? A: Chad A. Verdi Well, that's a tough one. I guess I am the most excited about NXTD right now, only because they are about to launch the Wocket™ this month. Wocket™ is a smart wallet with a re-programmable single credit card device that operates under a secured system using biometrics. I feel it will change the way people make credit card payments worldwide. Everyone is trying to get in on this game with mobile payments, mobile wallets, mobile apps like LOOP and COIN. Everyone is trying to figure out the best way to do it. I think Wocket™ has the right approach; separate from your phone. Most people are concerned about what happens if they lose their phone or it gets stolen - what happens with all that payment info on your phone? With Wocket™, it's not a worry because after each transaction it basically goes back to a blank card. Your identity and payment info are safe! It's great to think I originally invested in this a few years ago and now it may become the leader in the payment sector that I thought it would! Q: Investorideas.com In terms of your investments, you invest in both large companies like Apple and Yahoo and other big tech and entertainment companies but you also take risks and invest in smaller companies with emerging technology like NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Where do you see the biggest potential pay-off? A: Chad A. Verdi I obviously wish I would have had the opportunity to get into Apple from the beginning. I would have bet big on it, just like I have with NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Companies that take a different path from what the competition is doing represent the biggest opportunity, if it works. Steve Jobs set the course for Apple, I still love the company but it's hard to know if the vision will stay intact. NXTD is still young and they are taking a revolutionary approach to payments and identity issues, very different from their competitors and I like that. In my opinion, I see a big risk/reward opportunity here today because they have a product that every consumer will want and currently needs. The Wocket™ can store over 10,000 credit cards/coupons, under a secured system. It's never been done before. If they are successful in delivering this product; the sky is the limit. They could be the next Apple and that is my second-largest holding. Q: Investorideas.com The company stated that they will launch the Wocket™ May 28th at the Plaza Hotel in New York and will be taking advance orders for the Wocket™ once the event is done. Will you be attending and will you be buying one once advance orders are opened up? A: Chad A. Verdi For sure I will be there supporting them and seeing first-hand how the Wocket™ is embraced. And of course, I will be buying many, many Wockets™! I will be giving them out to all of my actor and celebrity friends in Hollywood. Soon, you may see a Wocket™ in a very famous pocket! I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. Verdi Music and Talent Supervisor Media Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4090091About InvestorIdeas.com: InvestorIdeas.com is a global news source covering leading sectors including biotech stocks tech and mobile stocks, mining, energy, waters stocks, renewable energy stocks, beverage stocks and more. urn:contentItem:555H-T7G1-JCDY-T54N-00000-00No Headline In Original2012-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisA sectionPg. A10

OVERSIGHT Ex-panel blasts tax break for AIG

Former members of a congressional panel that oversaw bailouts during the financial crisis blasted the Treasury Department on Monday for quietly granting a tax break worth billions to insurance giant American International Group.

The tax break amounts to a "stealth bailout" on top of the $182 billion that AIG received from the government, and it unfairly helps AIG, its shareholders and executives, former oversight panel chairman Elizabeth Warren and others said.

Warren, who also is a consumer advocate and Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate from Massachusetts, told reporters that tax breaks accounted for 90 percent of AIG profits last quarter. "We think it's time for Congress to end the special tax break," she said.

Companies sometimes defer losses and use them to reduce the tax burden in future years. Companies that change ownership usually face strict limits on how much of a loss they can defer. But Treasury granted AIG an exemption, handing the company $17.7 billion in profit, the former panel members said.

Damon Silvers, former vice chairman of the oversight panel, said the tax break unfairly benefits private AIG stockholders, including executives who were paid in stock options, at the expense of taxpayers.

"By doing it this way, substantial amounts of money leaked out to the benefit of private parties who really should not be benefiting from public policy in this way," Silvers said. He said the waiver gives AIG an unfair competitive advantage.

- Associated Press

LEGAL Yahoo sues Facebook over patents

Yahoo is filing a lawsuit against Facebook over patents, following through on a threat it made last month.

Yahoo said in a court filing Monday that Facebook has infringed 10 of its patents covering advertising, privacy controls and social networking.

Yahoo threatened to sue Facebook last month, insisting that the social network license its patents.

Facebook said it is disappointed in Yahoo and pledges to defend itself vigorously against what it calls "puzzling actions."

The patent claims could cast a spotlight on Facebook's vulnerabilities as it tries to complete an initial public offering of stock this spring. At the end of 2011, only 56 U.S. patents had been issued to Facebook - a relatively small number compared with other big tech companies.

- Associated Press

Also in Business

l Youku, owner of China's most- popular online video site, plans to acquire smaller competitor Tudou Holdings in a $1 billion stock deal that will help lower costs for licensing and transmitting content. The proposed deal will strengthen the new company's ability to compete with Baidu and Tencent Holdings in adding online video users in a nation where Google's YouTube is restricted. Youku and Tudou together accounted for more than a third of China's Web video advertising revenue last quarter, according to research company Analysys International.

l Federal safety regulatorsare investigating complaints that accelerators can stick in Ford Tauruses from model years 2005 and 2006. The investigation covers an estimated 360,000 of the sedans. So far, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has not ordered a recall.

l Apple confirmed that it has run out of new iPad tablet computers available for pre-order on the Internet, with a message on Apple's online store telling customers that it will be two to three weeks before an iPad will arrive. So if you want to own the new iPad on the first day it's available, prepare to wait at an Apple Store.

l An executivewith the PayPal online payment service was struck and killed by a commuter train in Northern California. San Mateo County coroner's investigators on Sunday identified the victim as 39-year-old Eric Salvatierra of Palo Alto, vice president of online payment service PayPal, where he's worked for about five years.

- From news services

Coming Today

l 8:30 a.m.:Retail sales report.

l 2:15 p.m.:Announcement by Federal Reserve's policymaking Federal Open Market Committee.

l Earnings:German automaker BMW, Books-A-Million.

WEREN'T HERE -- ALEXIS: YOU WERE THINKING ABOUT ME? PETER: IT WAS THE BEST SUPER BOWL GAME I WATCHED. IT WAS AMAZING. ALEXIS: ME, TOO. WE'RE HAVING SOME DISPUTES ABOUT THE JETS-COLTS SUPER BOWL IN THE CONTROL ROOM. ANYHOW, IT'S SUPER TUESDAY TODAY AND REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL MITT ROMNEY IS STILL CRITICIZING JOHN MCCAIN FOR HIS POSITIONS ON TAX CUTS AND HIS LACK OF BUSINESS BACKGROUND. BUT MCCAIN IS STILL LEADING IN THE POLLS. WE'LL TALK ABOUT HOW MUCH OF A FACTOR THE ECONOMY STILL PLAYS IN TODAY'S CONTEST AND WHAT CANDIDATES PLAN TO DO ABOUT THE DETERIORATING HOUSING MARKET. AND THEN -- THIS IS SO EXCITING -- IT'S HIS 12TH SEASON AS A LAKER. NUMBER 24 IS HERE TO TALK ABOUT HOW THE LOS ANGELES TEAM HELPED HIM BECOME AN NBA ICON AND HOW HE'S HELPED MARKET THE GAME OF BASKETBALL. KOBE BRYANT IS HERE IN THE STUDIO. AND, OF COURSE, YOU WON'T WANT TO MISS IT. THIS IS LIKE A RIDICULOUSLY FUN DAY FOR ME. [LAUGHTER] PETER: OUR RESIDENT JOCK, ALEXIS GLICK. ALEXIS: THERE YOU GO. PETER: MICROSOFT'S BILLION DOLLARS TAKEOVER BID, WE'LL TALK ABOUT THE REGULATORY HURDLE THE SOFTWARE GIANT IS FACING IN GETTING THAT DEAL DONE. PLUS WE'LL LOOK AHEAD IF MICROSOFT GETS THE DEAL DONE, COULD IT CAUSE A RIPPLE EFFECT IN THE TECH SECTOR? WE'LL TELL YOU WHERE THE NEXT BIG TECH DEAL COULD COME FROM. AND WITH RISING FUEL PRICES JACKING UP THE COST OF AIRLINE TICKETS, FREE FOOD ON AIRPLANES SOUNDS LIKE A PRETTY GOOD DEAL. WHILE IN TODAY'S LANDING ZONE, WE'LL TELL YOU WHY JETBLUE IS SERVING UP PHILADELPHIA CREAM CHEESE AT 35,000 FEET. BUT FIRST LET'S CHECK IN WITH CONNELL McSHANE UP AT THE FOX BUSINESS DESK. CONNELL. CONNELL: GOOD MORNING, PETER. WE HAVE NUMBERS FROM DUKE ENERGY. THE NUMBERS ON FIRST GLANCE LOOK TO BE BELOW WHAT THE STREET WAS EXPECTING. 21 CENTS A SHARE IS WHAT DUKE HAS REPORTED. THE AVERAGE ANALYST ESTIMATE WAS FOR EARNINGS OF 24 CENTS. DUK, THE TICKER ON DUKE ENERGY. SO KEEP AN EYE ON THAT STOCK TODAY. NOW, EARNINGS SEASON WINDING DOWN TO SOME EXTENT. WE HAVE A NUMBER OF COMPANIES THAT HAVE REPORTED ALREADY THIS MORNING. IN ADDITION TO THAT NUMBER THAT YOU'RE LOOKING AT FROM DUKE ENERGY ON YOUR SCREEN RIGHT NOW, WE HAVE NUMBERS OUT FROM TYCO INTERNATIONAL, THE CONGLOMERATE WHICH REALLY HANDILY TOPPED WHAT WALL STREET WAS EXPECTING THE COMPANY TO REPORT THIS MORNING. 73 CENTS A SHARE IS WHAT TYCO CAME IN AT. THAT'S A WIDE MARGIN BETTER THAN THE 57 CENTS THAN ANALYSTS HAD BEEN EXPECTING. TYCO REPORTING STRONG PROFIT GAINS ACROSS MOST OF ITS BUSINESSES. PROFIT WAS DOWN MORE THAN 50% FROM A YEAR AGO, BUT THAT HAD A LOT TO DO WITH RESTRUCTURING CHARGES AND WHAT HAVE YOU. EASILY TOPPING WALL STREET EXPECTATIONS FOR TYCO INTERNATIONAL. >>> ALSO OUT OF THE JAPANESE MARKET THIS MORNING, TOYOTA REPORTED AFTER THE JAPANESE MARKETS HAD CLOSED, BUT SOMETHING WE'LL CERTAINLY WATCH WITH ALL THE COMPETITION IN THE UNITED STATES WITH GM AND FORD. TOYOTA'S PROFITS AS YOU SEE THE BOTTOM OF YOUR SCREEN, UP YEAR OVER YEAR, UP BY 7-1/2%. A LOT OF PEOPLE BUYING TOYOTA CARS IN CHINA AND RUSSIA. THAT'S REALLY WHAT HELPED THE PROFITS OF TOYOTA. THE EMERGING MARKETS. THE U.S. MARKET IS SLOWING DOWN. SO THE OUTLOOK FROM TOYOTA WAS A BIT CAUTIOUS, IT WAS BELOW WHAT SOME ANALYSTS HAD BEEN EXPECTING. >>> NOW, LOOKING BACK AT THE DUKE ENERGY NUMBER I TOLD YOU A MOMENT AGO, WE TOLD YOU IT WAS 21 CENTS A SHARE. BUT IT LOOKS LIKE THE EX ITEMS NUMBER WHICH WOULD BE COMPARABLE TO WHAT THE STREET WAS LOOKING FOR, MAYBE 27 CENTS A SHARE. IF THAT'S THE CASE, THAT'S 3 CENTS BETTER THAN EXPECTATIONS FOR DUKE ENERGY. ALEXIS, BACK TO YOU. ALEXIS: THANKS SO MUCH, CONNELL. FORMER MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR MITT ROMNEY HAS BASHED JOHN MCCAIN. IT DIDN'T STOP STEVE FORBES FROM ENDORSING MCCAIN YESTERDAY. IF ECONOMY IS A TOP ISSUE IN THE PRIMARIES, LYING UNDERNEATH IS THE HOUSING AND MORTGAGE MESS. ON THIS SUPER TUESDAY, WE BREAKDOWN THE FOUR FINAL WHITE HOUSE HOPEFULS. MCCAIN, ROMNEY, CLINTON AND OBAMA. HERE TO HELP US IS FOX POLITICAL ANALYST ANDREW. AND BETH IS THE SENIOR EDITOR . GOOD MORNING. >> GOOD MORNING. ALEXIS: BETH, LET'S START WITH YOU AND THE HOUSING ISSUE AND THE SUBPRIME CRISIS. IT HAS CERTAINLY BEEN ONE OF THE BIGGEST ISSUES FACING AMERICANS ACROSS THE COUNTRY. DOES THAT, THEN, LEND SOME CREDENCE, YOU WOULD THINK, TO HILLARY CLINTON AND MITT ROMNEY WHO HAVE TALKED A LOT ABOUT HOUSING ON THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL? >> WELL, I CERTAINLY THINK THAT HILLARY IS GOING TO PLAY IT UP. AND YOU WILL BE HEARING HER TALKING ABOUT HER EXPERIENCE WORKING IN THE SENATE ON FINANCIAL ISSUES AND, YOU KNOW, KNOWING HOW TO BRING THESE ISSUES TO CONGRESS AND WORK WITH CONGRESS ON THESE ISSUES. OBVIOUSLY ROMNEY IS GOING TO TALK ABOUT HIS EXPERIENCE AS GOVERNOR, AS RUNNING THE OLYMPICS IN SALT LAKE CITY. HE'S GOING TO BE TALKIN

AND HARLEY DAVIDSON SAYS THEY WILL SELL FEWER HOGS. STOCK DOWN 9% FOR BOTH OF THOSE. >> ALL BUT TWO STOCKS IN THE NASDAQ ARE DOWN TODAY. TECHNOLOGY STOCKS ARE THE BIGGEST LOSERS AMONG THEM. >> WE HAVE BEEN SAYING THIS THE WHOLE DAY, AND I CANNOT SAY ENOUGH. TECHNOLOGY REALLY BEING DRAGGED DOWN. YOU HAVE THE NASDAQ BEING DRAGGED DOWN BY TECHNOLOGY STOCKS. NASDAQ COMPUTER INDEX DOWN 2.3%. THEN YOU HAD XILINX COME OUT AND SAY THAT REVENUES ARE GOING TO BE LITTLE CHANGE FROM LAST QUARTER AND THE SALES WILL BE FLAT TO SLIGHTLY DOWN. THAT DID NOT REALLY HELP OTHER CHIP STOCKS. INTEL IS DOWN ALMOST 3 PERCENT AS WELL. THEN, IT COULD STEEP TERRACED OF THE BIG TECH NAMES. APPLE ALREADY DOWN FOR THE ENTIRE WEEK. IT STARTED OFF ON TUESDAY AT ABOUT $144 A SHARE. AND THAT SHOULD HAVE HELPED THE STOCK, BUT NOT REALLY. YOU HAVE BROADER MARKET CONCERNS IMPACTING THEM AS WELL. YOU HAVE RESEARCH IN MOTION COME OUT AND ANNOUNCE A NEW PRODUCT AND NOTHING THAT ANY OF BLACKBERRY CURVE WITH A NEW CBS AND MAPPING SYSTEM. THAT SHOULD HELP THE STOCK, BUT NOT REALLY. IT HAS BEEN A DOWN DAY FOR TECHNOLOGY. THE NASDAQ CLIMBED LOWER AND LOWER ON THE BACK OF PRESSURE. THIS IS USUALLY AN INDUSTRY THAT INVESTORS SAY IS A SAFE HAVEN WHEN THERE IS A TIME OF VOLATILE MARKETS, BUT THAT HAS NOT REALLY HAPPENED. BACK TO YOU. >> TIME NOW TO CHECK IN WITH PIMM FOX. HE IS GOING TO TELL US HOW SMALL AND MID-CAP STOCKS ARE PERFORMING TODAY. LET ME GUESS THE ANSWER. >> OBVIOUSLY. THE RUSSELL 2000 IS ALSO DOWN MORE THAN 1%. PRICELINE.COM, BIOCHEMISTS, ALL LEADING THE INDEX LOWER TODAY. SHARES ARE LOWER BECAUSE OF A JUDGE'S RULING IN A PATENT DISPUTE OVER A GENETIC SEQUENCING TECHNOLOGY. THE REASON -- A DOWNGRADE FROM UNDERPERFORM TO NEUTRAL AND ENTERPRISE STARTED TO GO WITH IT. IN A NOTE TO INVESTORS, DAVIDSON SAID THAT CASCADE'S P/E RATIO MUCH HIGHER THAN ITS HISTORICAL AVERAGE. NOW, LET ME SHOW YOU WHAT IS HAPPENING AT TOWN SPORTS. THE FITNESS CLUB STOCK IS DOWN AS MUCH AS 8%. YOU CAN SEE THIS RIGHT HERE. AND THE STOCK WAS RATED A NEW CELL IN YOUR COVERAGE OVER AT BULK OF AMERICA -- BANK OF AMERICA. I NOTE DECLINES, BANK OF AMERICA SAID THAT MARGIN PRESSURE FROM THE ADDITION TO ALL THE NEWS IT IS THEIR OPENING IS NOT NECESSARILY FULLY PRICED INTO THE SHARE PRICE. TOM SPORTS IS THE NATION'S FIFTH LARGEST HEALTH CLUB CHAIN, AND IT HAS A STRATEGY OF OPENING HIGH-DENSITY OPERATIONS IN AREAS LIKE NEW YORK AND BOSTON. THEY ARE ACTUALLY NUMBER ONE IN NEW YORK. WHILE THE ALSO TARGET FAMILIES IN THEIR SUBURBAN LOCATIONS.

MONEY. SOME COMPANIES ARE LOOKING TO HELP SAVE THE PLANET AT THE SAME TIME. NEW YORK COULD LOSE ITS TITLE AS THE FINANCIAL CAPITAL OF THE WORLD. AND SOME BIG TECH COMPANIES GET READY TO OFFER UP THEIR PROFIT REPORT CARD.

ALEXIS CHRISTOFOROUS HAS MORE IN THIS MORNING'S MONEY WATCH. ---------- ANOTHER BIG WEEK FOR TECH STOCKS AS YAHOO AND CHIP GIANT A-M-D OFFER UP THEIR LATEST PROFIT REPROTS. INVESTORS ARE WORRIED THAT YAHOO'S REPORT WILL SHOW IT'S LOSING MORE GROUND TO GOOGLE. (VIDEO FROM INTEL) AND SUN MICROSYSTEMS ANNOUNCED A DEAL TO USE INTEL CHIPS IN ITS SERVERS -- A BIG BLOW TO RIVAL A-M-D... EBAY AND MICROSOFT REPORT EARNINGS LATER THIS WEEK. ONGOING CONCERN ABOUT THE HEALTH OF PROFITS IN THE TECH SECTOR HAS PUT PRESSURE ON STOCKS. ON MONDAY THE DOW CLOSED AT 12477.16 DOWN 88.37 THE NASDAQ CLOSED AT 2431.07 DOWN 20.24 NEW YORK IS AT RISK OF LOSING ITS TITLE AS THE FINANCIAL CAPITAL OF THE WORLD... THAT'S ACCORDING TO A REPORT COMMISSIONED BY MAYOR MICHAEL BLOOMBERG AND SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER. THE REPORT SAYS STIFF FINANCIAL REGULATIONS LIKE THE SARBANES- OXLEY ACT ARE HURTING THE FINANCIAL CLIMATE -- AND CAUSING NEW YORK AND OTHER U-S CITIES TO FALL BEHIND WHILE LONDON, HONG KONG AND TOKYO SURGE AHEAD AS FINANCIAL CENTERS. AND SOME BIG COMPANIES ARE TAKING A STAND FOR GOING GREEN... 10 CORPORATIONS INCLUDING GENERAL ELECTRIC, DUPONT AND ALCOA HAVE TEAMED UP WITH ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANZIATIONS TO URGE LAWMAKERS TO PASS SWEEPING LEGISLATION DESIGNED TO CUT GREENHOUSE GAS EMMISSIONS. WHILE THEY DON'T ENDORSE ANY PROPOSED LEGISLATION -- THE CALL DOES COME AHEAD OF TONIGHT'S STATE OF THE UNION ADDRESS FROM

urn:contentItem:56WP-7HX1-JBF5-T17C-00000-00No Headline In Original2012-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisSUNRISE ON K-5 AT 8:30AM8:34 AMWBN

STATION: 5 KFVE
Honolulu, HI

STABBED TO DEATH EARLIER THIS MONTH.. IN A STAIRWELL AT ALA MOANA CENTER. LE PLEADED 'NOT GUILTY' WHEN HE WAS IN COURT ON MONDAY. COURT DOCUMENTS SAY HE CONFESSED...TO STABBING KANAE.

LOOKING AHEAD, SHARON POMROY'S FAMILY IS PLANNING A MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR HER AT HER ANAHOLA FARM IN THE NEXT COUPLE WEEKS. THE OHA TRUSTEE CANDIDATE DIED TUESDAY MORNING AFTER SUFFEREING A SEIZURE AND FAMILY TELLS THE 'GARDEN ISLAND' THAT THE 'MERCHANT MARINES VETERAN' WAS BORN AS 'PETER POMROY' ON OCTOBER 10TH, 1949 ON OAHU AND TRANSITIONED TO SHARON AROUND 1980. DEVELOPING THIS MORNING. TUNISIA SAYS A 28-YEAR-OLD TUNISIAN HAS BEEN ARRESTED.. IN CONNECTION WITH THE US CONSULATE ATTACK IN LIBYA. MEANWHILE, A GOVERNMENT DOCUMENT SHOWS THAT TWO HOURS AFTER THE ATTACK, THE WHITE HOUSE WAS TOLD THAT A MILITANT GROUP WAS CLAIMING RESPONSIBILITY. A STATE DEPARTMENT EMAIL TO INTELLIGENCE OFFICIALS AND THE WHITE HOUSE SITUATION ROOM SAID THE CLAIM WAS MADE ON FACEBOOK AND TWITTER. BUT SECRETARY OF STATE CLINTON SAYS THE CLAIM DIDN'T PROVIDE DEFINITIVE EVIDENCE. THE DOCUMENT COULD FUEL REPUBLICAN EFFORTS TO SHOW THAT THE WHITE HOUSE KNEW IT WAS A TERRORIST ATTACK WHILE THE U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS WAS SAYING IT LOOKED LIKE IT STEMMED FROM A PROTEST. INCUE: IF THE PRESIDENT GIVES HIS COLLEGE RECORDS AND APPLICATIONS.. I WILL GIVE TO A CHARITY OF HIS CHOICE.. OUTCUE; A CHECK IMMEDIATELY FOR FIVE MILLION DOLLARS. THAT'S THE DONALD'S BIG ANNOUNCEMENT TODAY.. JUST 13 DAYS BEFORE THE ELECTION. HE SAID HE WILL RELEASE THE CHECK WITHIN ONE HOUR OF RELEASING THE RECORDS. HE THINKS IT'S A DEAL.. THAT THE PRESIDENT QUOTE 'CAN'T REFUSE.' THE PRESIDENCY IS NOT THE ONLY RACE AT STAKE ON ELECTION DAY. A HONOLULU CITY COUNCIL SEAT IS ALSO HOTLY CONTESTED. KYMBERLY PINE IS CHALLENGING COUNCILMAN TOM BERG FOR HIS SEAT REPRESENTING WEST OAHU. SHE SHOWED UP ON SUNRISE THIS MORNING.. SAYING THAT IF SHE'S ELECTED, SHE WILL LOOK FOR ALTERNATIVE IDEAS.. INSTEAD OF BUILDING A NEW LANDFILL. SHE ALSO SAID.. SHE WILL CONTINUE TO FIGHT FOR RAIL.. TO HELP RELIEVE CONGESTION.. FOR THE LEEWARD SIDE. INCUE: I THINK IT'S IMPORTANT: OUTCUE: TO HELP MY COMMUNITY WITH TRAFFIC RELIEF. PINE ALSO COMMENTED ON BERG'S NOTORIOUS TEMPER, SAYING AS A LAWMAKER, SHE NEVER HAD TO YELL TO REPRESENT HER CONSTITUENTS. THE IPAD-MINI IS OUT - NOW WAIT FOR THE NEXT BIG TECH LAUNCH - WINDOWS EIGHT. HOWARD DICUS HAS YOUR TECH NEWS. WINDOWS EIGHT COMES OUT THIS WEEK AND MICROSOFT'S FUTURE DEPENDS ON IT. THIS IS THE WINDOWS VERSION THAT IS SUPPOSED TO POWER TABLETS AND MOBILE DEVICES. ZD NET CALLS THE LAUNCH A BINARY EVENT - IT'LL THRIVE OR DIVE. AND ITS TESTERS SAY IT TAKES TIME TO LEARN BECAUSE IT'S NOT THAT INTUITIVE. THEY SAY IT WORKS WELL ON A TABLET BUT CAN BE ANNOYING ON A PC. MICROSOFT ALSO FACES TROUBLE FROM EUROPE. REGULATORS SAY IT PROMISED A WEB BROWER CHOICE FOR WINDOWS EIGHT BUT DIDN'T. IN OTHER TECH NEWS - THE IPAD-MINI COSTS MORE THAN

urn:contentItem:492M-CP70-01J8-W11C-00000-00No Headline In Original2003-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisSECTION A; BUSINESS BRIEFS; NATIONAL EDITION; Pg. A02

BUILDING

Buffett may face rival Clayton bid

Though Clayton Homes doubts Cerberus Capital will actually make an offer, shares of the manufactured home builder rose 3% to $13.41. Shareholders were set to vote July 16 on a $1.7 bil, $12.50-per-share bid from Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. The founding Clayton family supports the bid, but some big shareholders call it too low.

** An online charity auction for a lunch date with billionaire investor Warren Buffett fetched $250,100, nearly eight times more than the previous highest price paid. He's been auctioning lunches since '00.

FINANCE

SEC probes Morgan Stanley sales

The agency started a formal investigation into the investment bank's mutual fund sales practices on April 29, Morgan Stanley said in a quarterly filing with the SEC. U.S. regulators in May said they were examining how brokerages sell mutual funds to investors.

** Prudential Securities on Thursday agreed to pay $382,000 to settle charges regarding its mutual fund sales oversight. The SEC said the case wasn't related to the broader fund sales probe.

Lawyers to whittle down IPO suits

A judge ordered both sides of a class-action suit over rigged stock offerings to pare the litigation to a more manageable 10-20 cases. The suit involves 55 investment banks, more than 300 firms and millions of pages of documents. Plaintiffs say banks manipulated IPO prices with rosy research and overcharged clients for access to hot IPOs.

Agency probes Freddie Mac CEO

The Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight is trying to find out if Greg Parseghian, the mortgage firm's new CEO, was involved in Freddie Mac's accounting problems, published reports said. Freddie Mac on June 25 said it'll restate results for '00, '01 and '02 upward by up to $4.5 bil.

BofA reorganizes debt business

Bank of America will create a debt operating committee to oversee three product groups to boost profit. The groups are investment-grade, asset-backed and mortgage-backed securities; treasuries, agencies, derivatives, commodities and foreign exchange; and leveraged debt and loans. It was No. 3 in global loan syndication in the 1st half, Thomson Financial said.

U.S. wants Quattrone trial in N.Y.

Fallen Credit Suisse First Boston star Frank Quattrone wants a trial in Calif. instead, saying that's where the alleged obstruction of justice and witness tampering took place. He may also get a more sympathetic jury there, where he's known as a big tech booster. Prosecutors say the change of venue would delay the trial and that all the witnesses can testify in N.Y.

** UBS' chief global strategist Ed Kerschner will leave the Swiss bank at year-end. Gary Gordon will replace him.

Surprise at FEI: surprisingly weak first quarter

Hillsboro microscope maker FEI Co.reported surprisingly weak first-quarter sales and profits Tuesday, a rare disappointment from what had been Oregon’s best-performing big tech company. Shares fell 5.4 percent in after-hours trading.

FEI has reported strong sales growth in each of the past four years, benefiting from growth in the electronics and life sciences industries, and had forecast that 2014 could be its first with more than $1 billion in revenue. But the year is off to a tough start, with sales and profits below the company’s forecast range.

FEI shares fell $1.20 Tuesday, or 1.3 percent, closing at $88.80 before the company reported first-quarter results. FEI fell an additional $8.30 in extended trading.

— Mike Rogoway

SCHNITZER RULING: A federal jury in Portland has determined that Continental Casualty Co. and its subsidiary should pay $8.6 million to cover costs incurred by Portland’s Schnitzer Steel Industries to comply with regulators who oversee the Portland Harbor Superfund site.

The jury Monday in the court of U.S. District Judge Michael Mosman also said the Illinois-based insurer should pay Schnitzer attorneys’ and consultants’ fees, which haven’t been determined.

Lawyers for Schnitzer said they could not comment on the case until all legal proceedings are finished. Lawyers for Continental Casualty didn’t respond to requests for comment.

— Mike Francis

RITE-AID ACQUISITION: Rite-Aid, the Pennsylvania-based chain of drugstores, has acquired RediClinic, a chain of quick health care clinics inside H-E-B grocery stores in Texas.

That suggests that the company’s 71 stores in Oregon may soon offer vaccinations, smoking cessation programs, physicals, lipid panels and other quick health care services.

In general, after being beaten down for a few years, Rite-Aid is again impressing analysts with its plans. “The company continues to deliver healthy financial performance and improve its growth prospects,” reports Seeking Alpha.

— Mike Francis

$100 MILLION RAISED: New Relic, a San Francisco company that monitors how websites are performing and how visitors are using them, said Monday that it’s raised another $100 million in advance of a widely anticipated initial public stock offering.

The 6-year-old company made the unusual decision to put its engineering team in Portland, capitalizing on Oregon’s resurgent tech industry to build a large talent base far from Silicon Valley.

New Relic had previously disclosed $115 million in funding, including an $80 million round 14 months ago. Monday’s investment comes from BlackRock Passport Capital, with additional funding from T. Rowe Price Associates and Wellington Management.

The company doesn’t disclose financial information but had forecast that revenues would exceed $100 million in 2013.

— Mike Rogoway

browser bug: Windows XP users are getting their first taste of life without security updates after the discovery of a major flaw within the Internet Explorer Web browser.

Microsoft Corp. issued a warning regarding the flaw, saying it affects Internet Explorer versions 6 through 11. The vulnerability makes it possible for hackers to take control of a user’s computer after it has been infected with malicious code.

For now, security experts advise that Windows users avoid Internet Explorer until Microsoft issues a patch for the problem, which will likely happen May 13. But that patch will not protect users of Windows XP.

— Los Angeles Times

Q&A: Award Winning Movie Producer and Businessman Chad A. Verdi Discusses Hollywood Deals and Tech Investments in Apple and NXT-ID Inc.'s (OTCQB: NXTD) Wocket NEW YORK and POINT ROBERTS, Washington - May 19, 2014 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Verdi to Produce/Executive Produce Three Films with Oscar winning Director Martin Scorsese: Star studded actors include Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver "You may see a Wocket in a very famous Pocket" - C. Verdi Investorideas.com, a global news source covering leading topics and sectors including technology and entertainment, releases an exclusive Q&A with entrepreneurial movie producer, businessman and investor Chad A. Verdi of Rhode Island. Mr. Verdi discusses new and recent ventures including new movie deals and his investments in game-changing technologies, including Apple and biometric mobile security company NXT-ID Inc., (OTCQB: NXTD), which is currently preparing to launch its smart wallet, the Wocket™ (   www.wocketwallet.com), with advance orders starting May 28th. Mr. Verdi notes, "I am always looking ahead and I'm never satisfied with 'good enough', My goal is to partner with the best, hire the best talent and invest in leading edge companies.

Steve Jobs made Apple known for 'Think different', Richard Branson made his motto, 'Screw it , let's do it' and I live by 'Go big or go home'." Q&A Interview: Q: Investorideas.com This past year has already seen you reach some key milestones; making movies with the best in Hollywood, like Martin Scorsese and your investment in NXTD is up over 300 percent in less than a year. What are you most excited about for the balance of this year? A: Chad A. Verdi Well, that's a tough one. I guess I am the most excited about NXTD right now, only because they are about to launch the Wocket™ this month. Wocket™ is a smart wallet with a re-programmable single credit card device that operates under a secured system using biometrics. I feel it will change the way people make credit card payments worldwide. Everyone is trying to get in on this game with mobile payments, mobile wallets, mobile apps like LOOP and COIN. Everyone is trying to figure out the best way to do it. I think Wocket™ has the right approach; separate from your phone. Most people are concerned about what happens if they lose their phone or it gets stolen - what happens with all that payment info on your phone? With Wocket™, it's not a worry because after each transaction it basically goes back to a blank card. Your identity and payment info are safe! It's great to think I originally invested in this a few years ago and now it may become the leader in the payment sector that I thought it would! Q: Investorideas.com In terms of your investments, you invest in both large companies like Apple and Yahoo and other big tech and entertainment companies but you also take risks and invest in smaller companies with emerging technology like NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Where do you see the biggest potential pay-off? A: Chad A. Verdi I obviously wish I would have had the opportunity to get into Apple from the beginning. I would have bet big on it, just like I have with NXTD (OTCQB: NXTD). Companies that take a different path from what the competition is doing represent the biggest opportunity, if it works. Steve Jobs set the course for Apple, I still love the company but it's hard to know if the vision will stay intact. NXTD is still young and they are taking a revolutionary approach to payments and identity issues, very different from their competitors and I like that. In my opinion, I see a big risk/reward opportunity here today because they have a product that every consumer will want and currently needs. The Wocket™ can store over 10,000 credit cards/coupons, under a secured system. It's never been done before. If they are successful in delivering this product; the sky is the limit. They could be the next Apple and that is my second-largest holding. Q: Investorideas.com The company stated that they will launch the Wocket™ May 28th at the Plaza Hotel in New York and will be taking advance orders for the Wocket™ once the event is done. Will you be attending and will you be buying one once advance orders are opened up? A: Chad A. Verdi For sure I will be there supporting them and seeing first-hand how the Wocket™ is embraced. And of course, I will be buying many, many Wockets™! I will be giving them out to all of my actor and celebrity friends in Hollywood. Soon, you may see a Wocket™ in a very famous pocket! I also love the fact that the company is promoting the Wocket like Apple does with the launch of each IPhone - it's an event. They're running commercials on CNBC news along with using the Plaza hotel for the launch. They are also bringing in Miss Universe as a celebrity guest; it a first-class event. Q: Investorideas.com Speaking about Hollywood and movies, you and your wife Michelle are now involved in three projects with Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. According to IMDB you have signed on Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, Miles Teller, Aaron Eckhart and Adam Driver. On top of this, I read that you have signed a 10 picture deal with Screen Media films. It seems like you are on fire! How did this all come about? A: Chad A. Verdi Yes, it's just nuts, crazy nuts! It all started when Mr. Scorsese and his producing partner Emma Koskoff agreed to join my passion project,' Bleed for This'. My wife Michelle and I met with them a few times in New York and they invited us to the premiere of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. Then I was asked to get involved with a film called 'Bad Hurt' that was filmed in New York. Soon after that, things just escalated to where Michelle and I agreed to join Marty and Emma in his passion project called 'Silence'. The other two movies include 'The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument' and then we'll produce my passion project, 'Bleed For This', the true-life story of five-time world champion, Rhode Island boxer, Vinny Pazienza. Q: Investorideas.com That is exciting and all happening very fast. How many years will it take you to complete these four films and what about the ten picture deal with Screen Media? A: Chad A. Verdi That's what's amazing. Eighteen months in regards to the four films: Bad Hurt is in post-production right now along with A 50 Year Argument. Bleed for This and Silence will be filmed this fall with completion dates no later than fall 2015, just in time for the Oscars. As far as the 10 picture deal with Screen Media Films, we are currently filming the first film called 'Almost Mercy' now and expect to release that film in December 2014. Then we begin filming the 2nd film in early 2015. The goal is to meet our obligations on the 10 picture deal prior to 1/1/2018. We are able to facilitate this because we have two production companies, The Woodhaven Production Company and Verdi Productions. Both companies are working separately and independent of one another and this gives us the capacity to handle the volume of projects we are involved with. About the Verdi Productions and Woodhaven Production Company: Both Verdi Productions and The Woodhaven Production Company are fully funded film production companies, covering all aspects of filmmaking from conception of script through postproduction.http://www.woodhavenfilms.com/,   http://www.verdifilms.com/About Chad Verdi Chad A. Verdi, CEO: Chad A. Verdi is a producer and actor, known for Loosies (2011), Inkubus (2011) and Infected (2012). Full Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3838148/Michelle L. Verdi Music and Talent Supervisor Media Bio:   http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4090091About InvestorIdeas.com: InvestorIdeas.com is a global news source covering leading sectors including biotech stocks tech and mobile stocks, mining, energy, waters stocks, renewable energy stocks, beverage stocks and more. Follow Investorideas.com on Twitter   http://twitter.com/#!/InvestorideasFollow Investorideas.com on Facebook   http://www.facebook.com/InvestorideasFollow Investorideas.com News on Linkedin.com/today at   http://www.linkedin.com/today/investorideas.comSign up for the free investor news and stock alerts   http://www.investorideas.com/Resources/Newsletter.aspDisclaimer/ Disclosure: The Investorideas.com newswire is a third party publisher of news and research as well as creates original content as a news source. Original content created by investorideas is protected by copyright laws other than syndication rights. Nothing on our sites should be construed as an offer or solicitation to buy or sell products or securities. All investment involves risk and possible loss of investment. This site is currently compensated by featured companies, news submissions, content marketing and online advertising. Contact each company directly for press release questions. Disclosure is posted on each release if required but otherwise the news was not compensated for and is published for the sole interest of our readers. More disclaimer info:   http://www.investorideas.com/About/Disclaimer.aspDisclosure: Investorideas is currently compensated by NXTD: five thousand per month plus 144 shares from a previous agreement. Disclosure: Chad a Verdi is long NXTD share in NXTD BC Residents and Investor Disclaimer: Effective September 15 2008 - all BC investors should review all OTC and Pink sheet listed companies for adherence in new disclosure filings and filing appropriate documents with Sedar. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:3YYM-41D0-003M-X0B9-00000-00No Headline In Original2000-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisA; Pg. 24By Joseph Guinto, Investor's Business Daily

Congressman J.C. Watts, R-Okla., must have had deja vu on Monday. As he had done dozens of times while a star quarterback at the University of Oklahoma, Watts gathered teammates together, loaded them on a bus and sent them out to do battle. The team - a gaggle of GOP leaders - traveled from Capitol Hill to Virginia's tech-heavy Dulles corridor. The lawmakers visited companies there to see how they might help in the contest between cyber-criminals blitzing the Internet and cyber-security firms intent on blocking them. But for Watts, the deja vu ends there. For one thing, this is no game. The FBI says cybercrime costs companies and government $ 10 billion a year. And in a survey by the Computer Security Institute, 90% of companies polled said they've had a computer security breach in the last year. For another thing, the Internet industry's top firms have told federal legislators something Watts' coach, Barry Switzer, never imagined saying: "Ride the bench." Despite recent high-profile attacks in which hackers hobbled major sites like EBay and Yahoo, big tech companies haven't haven't embraced stronger cybercrime laws. "I do think we already have sufficient laws" to deal with cyber-security, said Michael Hershman, head of Decision Strategies Fairfax International, a security consulting firm. Some sound a more strident tone. Officials from Microsoft and Cisco Systems recently told a joint House-Senate panel on cybercrime that the industry can take care of itself. Howard Schmidt, Microsoft's chief information security officer, cautioned against any "unnecessary outside regulation or interference in the operation of dynamic, very productive businesses.

"Infrastructure security does not lend itself to government management," he said. The White House heard the same line when it brought 20 Internet industry executives together with academics and government officials just after major hacking attacks in February. After the meeting, White House officials said the industry representatives didn't ask for new legislation to fight back against hackers. When you consider the numbers, the industry's reluctance to pursue cyber-criminals seems funny. Cybercrime already has a broad impact. Just one prominent example, the Melissa virus of 1999, caused $ 80 million in damage worldwide. In a December incident, 300,000 credit card numbers were pulled from the databanks at CD Universe and posted on the Web. And the problem is expected to get worse. As more Internet users connect through high-speed modems such as cable and DSL lines, they'll be on the Net nearly nonstop. This will give hackers thousands more computers whose data they can dip into or whose Internet links they can exploit to commit crimes. The attackers are as varied as the crimes. Some are disgruntled employees looking to sabotage systems. Some are criminals looking to steal data and hold it for ransom. And some are teen-agers vandalizing a site for fun or cracking a company's security to expose its flaws. That vast potential number of cyber-attackers makes preventing cyberattacks almost impossible. The National Computer Security Center says 64% of U.S. corporations, government agencies and universities have already been victims of cybercrime. That's made fighting off attacks a 24-hour job for some. Like many of its members, the National Association of Securities Dealers says its Nasdaq.com Web pages are under constant assault. "We have 20 to 30 hacks ongoing at any given time," said Larry Bickner, vice president of information security for the association. Its response: more and more security programs to catch as many hackers as possible before they can do any damage. Given the rising costs, why haven't companies sought more government help in nabbing hackers? Some credit Silicon Valley's laissez-faire leanings. But there may be other concerns. "Companies just want to recover as much money as they can and slap the person on the wrist and get it over with," said Chuck Bowe, a risk management expert at KPMG. "They don't want to take action against the people they catch, because their customers will flee over the publicity." Indeed, the FBI says only 17% of the victims of cybercrime report the crimes committed against them. There's good reason to worry about bad publicity. When E-Trade Group, EBay, Buy.com and Amazon.com were among those hit in February, it made news across the country. Competitors know this, so they use hacking incidents against each other. When Russian mobsters pilfered $ 10 million from Citibank last year, the competition played it up. And they did so even though Citibank got back virtually all of the money. In addition to bad publicity from a public hunt for cyber-criminals, there's also a morass of private data issues to be considered. Among them: Should an Internet Service Provider open its logs to federal investigators? Will client confidentiality be compromised if the FBI checks through an e-commerce site's files? For now the industry seems content to take its chances. Harris Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America, told Congress the industry has "reservations about working too closely with the federal law enforcement and national security community and has concerns about jeopardizing business concerns by sharing information on security issues." Clearly the industry has reason to be concerned about federal intervention in cyber-security. While nearly all of the Net's infrastructure is private, government agencies use it a lot. Nearly 25% of all computers sold each year, for instance, go to government agencies. That risk helped lead the GOP team to the Dulles corridor Monday, and has led other lawmakers and agencies to propose beefed-up security measures. Among them: Several senators and representatives are backing proposals to create a federal clearinghouse for sharing information on cyberattacks. The clearinghouse would be protected against Freedom of Information requests and privacy liability. The FBI is doubling its force of digital investigators. It plans to have cybercrime units in all of its 56 field offices within two years. The Clinton administration wants $ 91 million for new technologies to combat cyber-terrorism. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison, R-Texas, is pushing a bill to double penalties for serious hacking offenses to 10 years in prison for the first offense and 20 for a second offense. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and others have introduced bills to give the FBI and other federal agencies more powers to investigate cybercrime around the world. Other initiatives would let federal investigators and prosecutors begin their work at the beginning of a hacking case. Under current law, you have to show more than $ 5,000 in damages before federal prosecution can start. Even with all the new proposals, federal officials have made it clear that they think private industry will have to look after itself. Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder told a joint House-Senate cyber-security panel that "we in government will not be able to solve all these problems. We believe the private sector should take the lead in protecting private computer networks." Alan Paller, a director at the SANS Institute, a research group linking nearly 100,000 computer managers and security professionals, hopes to do just that. SANS is promoting through its Web site free security tools that help prevent the kind of hacking that shut down Yahoo and crippled EBay, E-Trade and Amazon.com in February. While such measures aren't new, major Internet companies have been slow to adopt them because of cost.

It provided data on one of its brands only. It says nicotine levels in marlboro cigarettes were -- were the same in 2006 as in 1997. The last year the study looked at, however, was 2005. (menafn � ecpulse) The upcoming week will feature a testimony by the Federal Reserve`s Chairman Janet Yellen before the Congress. A busy week for earnings will include results from America`s biggest banks and tech companies. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen testifies on the central bank`s monetary policy, in a semi-annual appearance before the Senate and House.

Yellen is expected to hew closely to the Fed`s last policy statement. Investors will parse her comments closely for any signs that data released since the Fed`s last meeting has shifted the central bank`s thinking at all. The remarks, mandated by the Humphrey-Hawkins Full Employment Act of 1978, have Yellen speaking before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, and a House panel on Wednesday. The commerce department also releases the data for retail sales for June, expecting 0.6 percent of raise and the department issues business inventories for May on the same day. The commerce department is scheduled to issue housing starts for June on Thursday, while the labor department is expected to issue weekly Jobless Claims. From Google and Yahoo to General Electric, next week will bring a full range of corporate results as the earning season shifts into high gear. Earnings from some of the biggest U.S. technology companies will take center stage next week, giving investors a chance to re-evaluate the sector`s health. Big tech names set to report next week include Intel Corp and Yahoo Inc on Tuesday; eBay Inc on Wednesday and Google Inc on Thursday.

The tech sector has the highest projected earnings growth rate among the 10 S&P sectors for the second quarter at 12.3 percent, its best quarter since the first quarter of 2012. This forecast marks a sharp rebound from a drop of 3.2 percent just a year ago, according to a Thomson Reuters poll.

Goldman Sachs analysts wrote in a note that the information technology sector "appears to be the most undervalued sector," giving investors more reasons to be bullish on tech stocks.

The implied earnings-per-share growth for the tech sector has been 5.4 percentage points above the S&P 500 on average over the past 10 years, but it is now just 1.0 percentage point above the benchmark index, according to the Goldman Sachs note. Earnings from some of major banks next week will include JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs Group Inc on Tuesday, Bank of America Corp on Wednesday and Morgan Stanley on Thursday. Analysts are expecting subdued results because a slowdown in revenue from mortgage refinancing and trading is offsetting gains from other areas like investment banking and money management. Higher legal, regulatory and compliance costs are also weighing on results. Wells Fargo`s report on Friday underscored some of the problems as the largest U.S. mortgage lender reported a 39 percent decline in revenue from that business. BlackRock, the world`s largest money manager, is scheduled to report second-quarter earnings results on Wednesday morning before market open. Analysts expect the New York-based asset manager, which now manages more than $4.4 trillion inassets,to earn $4.41 per share, up from $4.15 per share a year ago. eBay, which is expected to report a 68 cents per share profit on Wednesday, also saw its traffic fall after Google updated its search engine, analysts said.

urn:contentItem:5T75-1JX1-JCBX-G194-00000-00No legislating for big tech - yet2018-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisSUNDAY BUSINESS;NEWSPg. 7No legislating for big tech - yetSTEVE DEMPSEY

T'S been an interesting seven days for social media platforms and big tech companies.

ILast Sunday the BBC director-general, and the chief executives of Sky, BT, ITV and Talk Talk wrote an open letter to the Telegraph calling for greater regulation of social media and technology companies that encroach on the media space.

And later in the week, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, and Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg, testified at a US Senate hearing about moderation of online content and interference in elections. Google representatives were invited, but didn't show. The upshot is that it seems more likely than ever that some form of legislation or regulation for social media and online platforms is on the way - on both sides of the Atlantic.

Let's start with the letter from the UK broadcasters and telcos. It's central point was that they invest in the UK economy and infrastructure, pay taxes and are regulated by Ofcom. This is in contrast to the giants of Silicon Valley, which lawfully avoid UK taxes and are almost entirely unregulated.

"There is an urgent need for independent scrutiny of the decisions taken, and greater transparency," the letter says. "This is not about censoring the internet, it is about making the most popular internet platforms safer, by ensuring there is accountability and transparency over the decisions these private companies are already taking."

They've got a point. While traditional media companies are subject to regulation, the tech bros are free to do what they want. This means inconsistent policies around hate-speech, promises that artificial intelligence will solve all problems, and denials that online platforms have the legal or social responsibilities of a media company. They aren't beholden to anyone other than their shareholders and their customers.

In effect this means a coven of bright but idealistic young men who live in Silicon Valley and have drunk the tech utopia Kool Aid are self-regulating the platforms they created, which have grown to have global influence. The reason they've gotten this far without regulation is the dominance of big tech's PR and lobbying machine, and the digital ignorance of legislators across the globe. But that's changing. The UK government has promised a white paper on internet safety that will propose policies to "ensure Britain is the safest place in the world to be online" - hence the public lobbying from traditional media players for some form of regulation of social platforms. Europe's GDPR and upcoming ePrivacy Directive place the digital consumer in the driving seat around how their online personal information is used and by whom.

In Germany, the Netzwerkdurchsetzungsgesetz law (don't you just love German legislation titles) enacted in January ensures that social networks with more than two million users have 24 hours to delete posts that contain Nazi symbolism, Holocaust denial and hate speech. If they don't they can be fined up to (EURO)50m.

But it's in the US - the home of Apple, Facebook, Google and Amazon - where things really need to change. Claims that social media platforms are biased against right-wing media overshadowed everything else at this week's hearings, but regulation was pretty prominent subplot. "Congress is going to have to take action here," said the democratic Senator Mark Warner (inset). "The era of the Wild West in social media is coming to an end."

The tech companies do seem to realise that regulation is inevitable. "I do believe there is growing concern around power companies like ours hold," Twitter's Dorsey said. "People do see us as a digital public square and that comes with certain expectations."

But the platforms still want to regulate themselves. Mind you, some have stated their support for the Honest Ads Act, which would require companies to disclose how political advertisements are targeted and how much is spent on them.

But, to date, there's been no mention of any changes to the 1996 Communications Decency Act that states interactive media services aren't publishers, and aren't liable for any offending material uploaded, provided they take some action to take it down. The US holds a prominent position in relation to how these new global platforms are regulated.

Sure, some regulator for social media that reports to Ofcom in the UK is needed - but until US legislators make the big tech platforms liable for defamation or copyright infringements, tackle misinformation or follow the lead of the EU with its GDPR, it'll take more than a strongly worded letter to change things for the better.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XV8-9M71-DYVR-P119-00000-00No Longer Enamored, Washington Looks Critically at Silicon Valley2019-12-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisVOA ENGLISH SERVICENo Longer Enamored, Washington Looks Critically at Silicon ValleyMichelle Quinn

No Longer Enamored, Washington Looks Critically at Silicon Valley

By Michelle Quinn

December 26, 2019 04:34 AM

SAN FRANCISCO - The era of Silicon Valley operating largely free from government regulation may be coming to an end.

In 2019, lawmakers grilled tech executives at multiple hearings in Washington and federal regulators slapped record fines on tech firms. They promise action in the coming year on a host of issues: competition, online privacy, encryption and bias.

U.S. tech companies such as Apple, Facebook, Google and Amazon are girding themselves for more federal scrutiny.

"As the internet companies matured without a lot of regulation, some issues have emerged where attention is needed," said Rep. Zoe Lofgren, a Democrat representing Silicon Valley since 1994 and who has introduced a national online privacy bill.

"I think it's fair enough to examine what kind of rules should be set in certain elements of the tech economy," she said.

For years, Washington was enamored with the technology industry and its iconic companies that fueled economic growth. They created new tools for campaigning and reaching voters, and enjoyed an aura of cool.

Online privacy and user data

Now, there are threats of fines over things such as violating users' privacy or stifling competition.

In 2019, the Federal Trade Commission issued a record $5 billion fine against Facebook for "deceiving users about their ability to control the privacy of their personal information." It also issued a $170 million fine against Google for violating children's privacy on YouTube, which Google owns.

New laws, such as the one Lofgren proposes, could give American users more control over their online data and limit companies' ability to collect user data. Those moves could limit companies' ability to sell advertising, which funds the free internet.

Antitrust and competition

Both Democrats and Republicans criticize "Big Tech," as it is now called. And in the coming year, the pressure will likely increase.

"Whenever the word 'Big' is placed before your industry, it's not a good thing," said Carl Guardino, president and chief executive of the Silicon Valley Leadership Group, which represents many of the region's tech firms. "It's now 'Big Tech,' and you know it's not used as a term of endearment."

Foreign users of American tech products could also see changes if Washington follows through on threats to break up large companies like Facebook. Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren is reportedly drafting a bill (https://www.cnbc.com/2019/12/07/warrens-antitrust-bill-would-boost-government-control-over-biggest-companies.html)to toughen the country's rules about antitrust and competition.

The Federal Trade Commission is reportedly looking into stopping Facebook's further integration of Whatsapp and Instagram (https://www.wsj.com/articles/ftc-weighs-seeking-injunction-against-facebook-over-how-its-apps-interact-11576178055), in case it would one day see a need to break up the social network giant.

Washington seems to have woken up to the dangers of technology companies that have become the gatekeepers of communications and commerce, said Sally Hubbard, the director of enforcement strategy at the Open Markets Institute, a research group that focuses on antitrust issues.

"The traction has definitely really intensified over the last year," she said. "There's also just a growing awareness that these companies are causing a wide range of harms, whether it's harms to our democracy, harms to innovation, harms to entrepreneurship. They are playing the game and controlling it, too."

China and 5G infrastructure

Meanwhile, there is growing concern over China's expanding role in advanced global communications and whether the authoritarian country can be entrusted with user data. The U.S. government has warned other countries not to work with the Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei, which sells equipment that is building the new 5G networks around the world.

Much is at stake. With more than a majority of the Earth's 7 billion people online, Washington's rules for the U.S. technology industry and its global competitors could determine the future of communication.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YC5-6D71-F0YC-N0FM-00000-00No matter which way you look at it, tech jobs are still concentrating in just a few cities2020-03-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:15ZLexisNexisNo matter which way you look at it, tech jobs are still concentrating in just a few cities

Washington DC: Brookings Institution has issued the following press release:

In December, Brookings Metro and Robert Atkinson of the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation released a report noting that 90% of the nation’s innovation sector employment growth in the last 15 years was generated in just five major coastal cities: Seattle, Boston, San Francisco, San Diego, and San Jose, Calif.

This finding sparked appropriate consternation, but also some disbelief. Perhaps, some suggested, Big Tech is becoming less concentrated if one considers digital services industries such as computer systems design, which our definition of the “innovation sector” omitted. Those industries could be more footloose and likely to stray from large coastal cities and into the heartland.

Unfortunately, thenew analysis we produced for the American Enterprise Institute on the geography of digital services industries doesn’t show this. In fact, it shows the opposite: more divergence between the metropolitan “winners” and also-rans. Tech—as epitomized by the four key digital services industries we studied—is concentrating rather than spreading out.

Sure, dozens of snappy startups are launching in places like Akron, Ohio, Memphis, Tenn., and Louisville, Ky.—enough so that metro areas across America have added tech jobs since 2010. But even so, digital tech by our measure has continued to concentrate in a short list of major cities over the decade, rather than disperse outwards. As such, many metro areas are losing their shares of the overall tech sector even as they grow.

The upshot is sobering: “Winner-take-most” seems more the rule than the hoped-for“rise of the rest.” And that’s a problem we will need to confront more directly than we have until now.

What specifically does the new data show? The story isn’t great. Expanding on our last look at tech location trends from late 2018, this new analysis of job creation in four digital services industries finds that superficial good news masks deeper-set problems.

To be clear, tech remains a compelling contributor to regional growth, and is, in fact, growing in new places. Specifically, digital services continues as a critical part of the national economy, accounting for 80% of the nation’s advanced industries growth from 2010 to 2018, as employment grew 4.2% a year based on compound annual growth rate (CAGR) calculations. Likewise, unexpected heartland metro areas far from the coastal hubs surfaced as fast-growing tech centers in the 2010s. Among the 100 largest U.S metro areas, for example, Charleston, S.C , Charlotte, N.C , Lakeland-Winter Haven, Fla., Boise, Idaho, and Wichita, Kan. all posted digital services growth of over 7% per year over the decade. Midwestern stalwarts Kansas City, Mo., Madison, Wis., and Indianapolis all saw yearly growth of more than 6%.

In short, it’s absolutely true that tens of thousands of digital services jobs—central to the current artificial intelligence-driven tech boom—are sprouting in up-and-coming heartland towns. And with those jobs comes growth, hope, good pay, and attractive economic multiplier effects.

Table 1

But that’s just the surface story. Deeper analysis of tech’s shifting structure clearly shows that although more cities are enjoying a mathematical rise in the number of tech jobs, the sector has been rapidly concentrating all decade. This dynamic may reflect the rising importance of giant agglomerations of talent and firms in periods of tech disruption, as with the decade’s waves of social media and artificial intelligence innovation. It might reflect the continued groupthink of tech industry managers and funders about siting decisions. Or, it might reflect the geographic effect ofmonopolistic “platforms” in Big Tech, which may prevent the entry of geographical as well as corporate rivals.

The numbers are eye-popping. The top five metro areas with the highest shares of the nation’s digital services industry accounted for 28% of all of these jobs nationwide in 2018, while the top 10 encompassed 44.3%. The same top 10 metro areas captured almost half (47.9%) of the nation’s new tech jobs from 2010 to 2018, with five of them—San Francisco, Seattle, San Jose, Los Angeles, and Austin, Texas—increasing their share of the nation’s tech work especially fast. Those five alone captured 28% of all new digital services job growth and increased their share of the nation’s core tech employment by 1.8 percentage points.​

Table 2

To put a finer point on the trend, consider that tech’s most elite “superstar” cities—San Francisco and San Jose—ascended even further in the 2010s. San Francisco added over 10% of the nation’s new digital services jobs (roughly 110,000), while San Jose accounted for nearly 8% of such jobs, or about 83,000. Together, the two hubs have added 200,000 digital services jobs since 2010 and now concentrate some 11% of the nation’s digital services employment, up from 10.1% in 2015 and 7.5% in 2010. The two also captured a whopping 17.7% of the decade’s new tech employment, and today house nearly 350,000 of the nation’s 3.1 million total tech jobs

Meanwhile, only a few cities in the rest of the country have truly “risen” in the last couple of years and expanded their share of the nation’s digital services employment. Just seven of the largest 100 metro areas in the nation increased their share of the sector by more than two-tenths of a percentage point. In the heartland, only Charlotte, N.C , Denver, and Phoenix are among them. Only nine additional metro areas in the largest 100—including inland centers such as Dallas, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Mo., and Provo, Utah—managed to increase their share of the nation’s digital services sector by at least one-tenth of a percentage point.​

Figure 1

Otherwise, progress toward a more geographically balanced tech sector was modest to vanishingly slight in the last decade. Just 21 cities saw their sector share increase between 2010 and 2018, albeit via gains of less than one-tenth of a percent. This group was led by Raleigh, N.C and includes a number of up-and-coming interior Midwestern and Southern cities such as Pittsburgh, Akron, Greenville, S.C , Grand Rapids, Mich., Chattanooga, Tenn., Spokane, Wash., and Salt Lake City. Although many of these cities made steady progress, they are not significantly increasing their share of the national digital services sector or demonstrating compelling competitiveness.

As for the rest of the nation’s 100 larger metro regions, no less than 63 saw their share of the sector decline due to slow or negative growth. Metro areas such as Providence, R.I , Little Rock, Ark., Virginia Beach, Va., and Stockton, Calif. lost 5% or more of their digital services employment between 2010 and 2018.

The verdict of the data is sobering, then: While tech’s superstar cities have captured the lion’s share of job creation in digital services, their immoderate success has not triggered any sort of self-regulating equilibrium process by which the nation’s stark geographic divides might begin to ease. Even as the tech sector continues to raise hopes for broad economic transformation in the nation’s interior, it is continuing to reflect—and drive—a “winner-take-most” result. At a time when the nation badly needs to reconnect left-behind people and places to prosperity, tech’s inherent tendency to facilitate geographic agglomeration is only sharpening the nation’s divides.

So, what is it going to take to moderate this tendency and perhaps to spur tech sector growth in new places? Having tracked these trends through the decade, I think the case for concerted national action is now clear, as Atkinson and I previously argued.

The tech economy is unleashing forces that benefit only select group of elite regions, often to the detriment of everyone else. These dynamics are circular, cumulative, and massively scaled. Therefore, they call for a nation-scaled response.

What might such a response look like? At least one part needs to be a national innovation response, one that fundamentally intervenes to alter the country’s entrenched tech map. This is the intent of our proposal for a major tech innovation “surge” that would counter regional divergence by mounting a national competition to create eight to 10 new innovation-driven “growth centers” across the heartland. The plan would be to focus transformative R&D, workforce inclusion, and “placemaking” investment on a limited number of locations as part of a deliberate effort to catalyze the innovation sector takeoff of those regions and develop new tech centers in new places. The same type of federal, place-based innovation surge that created Silicon Valley less intentionally could be updated to do the same for America’s left-behind regions.

But this is just one idea; others can certainly be imagined. We likely need a strategy for reinvigorating hundreds of solid but stagnant communities that lack a plausible innovation “play” of the sort that the growth centers proposal seeks to catalyze. And we need some kind of response to the crisis of the truly left-behind places: the deeply distressed smaller towns and rural areas that have lost their economic purpose and are now stuck in corrosive traps of nonparticipation and underdevelopment.

What is increasingly clear, though, is that tech-based growth will likely not diffuse out into America’s up-and-coming midsized cities and small towns on its own. Instead, it’s going to take tougher action from a concerned nation to counter this excessive concentration and spark new vitality across the heartland.
